The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob.     "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to marry \u201canti\u2010parity\u2010time\u201d (anti\u2010PT) non-Hermitian operations with a Pytheus-compatible quantum network (swapping or teleportation style) without simply generating a new state.  \n  1. Insert a heralded, non\u2010unitary \u201canti-PT filter\u201d into an entanglement-swapping link and study the threshold for swapped entanglement.  \n  2. Build a three-node teleportation protocol in which the central Bell-measurement node is replaced by an anti-PT non-reciprocal coupler realized by post-selected linear optics.  \n  3. Use two Bell pairs, send one photon of each through pairwise anti-PT couplers (with differing loss/gain ancillas), then perform a joint measurement to route entanglement around a loop and test directional nonlocality.  \n\nStep 2: Quick novelty check and Pytheus hurdles  \n  1. No entanglement-swapping experiment to date has embedded a heralded non-unitary anti-PT filter. Pytheus can do heralding, ancillas, BS\u2019s. Good.  \n  2. Replacing the BSM by an anti-PT coupler is interesting but overlaps strongly with idea 1 once you add heralding.  \n  3. A loop network with two couplers is more complex and might be hard to pin down as a single clear-cut target.  \n\nStep 3: Pick idea 1 as most promising: It\u2019s a clear quantum network (entanglement swapping), it focuses on a non-unitary transformation (the anti-PT filter) rather than pure state generation, and it uses only SPDC sources, single-photon ancillas, beam splitters, and detectors.  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no one has combined an anti-PT non-Hermitian operation\u2014heralded via post-selected linear optics\u2014with an entanglement\u2010swapping network to witness a non-Hermitian phase transition in the entanglement fidelity.  \n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because the filter is realized with ancilla photons and beam splitters (all linear-optical, post\u2010selected), the swapping uses two SPDC sources and a Bell-measurement node, and we only require no dynamic feedback control.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nWe propose a \u201cHeralded Anti-PT Filter in an Entanglement-Swapping Network.\u201d  \n\nExplanation:\nWe take two standard spontaneous-parametric-down\u2010conversion (SPDC) sources producing Bell pairs A\u2013C and B\u2013D. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d  \n\u2013 Feasible: uses only SPDC, heralded single photons, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n\u2013 Expands: once the basic filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Superposition of Entanglement Swapping and Purification\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose a fully passive linear\u2010optical chip that employs a single\u2010photon control qubit in state |+\u3009\u2080 to coherently superpose two Bell\u2010pair network operations\u2014entanglement swapping between nodes A and D and parity\u2010check purification of nodes A and B\u2014using only SPDC sources, a control\u2010switch interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors. The device targets the transformation  \n|+\u3009\u2080\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{1,2}\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{3,4} \u2192 |0\u3009\u2080\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,D} + |1\u3009\u2080\u2297\u03c1^{pur}_{A,B},  \nheralded by distinct detection patterns, thereby realizing a new higher\u2010order quantum network primitive for programmable photonic processors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. By employing entangled ancilla photon-pair sources, a configurable multiport interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters, and heralded number-resolving detection, our purely linear-optical protocol enacts the non-unitary Kraus decomposition of the anyonic braid map without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable Teleportation of CNOT and SWAP Gates onto Two Neutral-Atom Qubits\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a fixed interferometer module that, depending on the internal state of a control atom (C) and heralding detector clicks, teleports either a CNOT\u208dA\u2192B\u208e or SWAP\u208dA\u2194B\u208e gate onto two remote target neutral-atom qubits A and B. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal of embedding an \u201canti-PT\u201d nonunitary filter stage into an entanglement-swapping network is essentially a rebranding of the PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter ideas already in the ensemble (see \u201cPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\u201d and \u201cPT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\u201d). Swapping in a slight change of nomenclature (anti-PT vs PT) does not introduce a genuinely new network primitive or measurement effect beyond those established proposals.\n\nAction: reject\n\nAction Input: The concept of a tunable non-Hermitian filter embedded before Bell measurements to threshold entanglement appearance has already been covered by the PT-symmetric filter\u2010enhanced teleportation/CNOT and PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping suggestions. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The concept of a tunable non-Hermitian filter embedded before Bell measurements to threshold entanglement appearance has already been covered by the     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to marry anti-PT non-Hermitian operations with a Pytheus-compatible quantum network primitive (swapping or teleportation) without simply \u201cgenerating a new target state\u201d:\n  1. Insert a heralded, non-unitary \u201canti-PT filter\u201d into an entanglement-swapping link and study the threshold (exceptional point) for swapped entanglement.\n  2. Replace the Bell-measurement in a three-node teleportation protocol by a post-selected anti-PT coupler, creating directional teleportation.\n  3. Create a small loop network of two swapping nodes connected by anti-PT couplers and probe non-reciprocal entanglement percolation.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty and Pytheus-feasibility check:\n  1. No one has embedded a heralded anti-PT filter into entanglement swapping. Pytheus can handle ancilla photons, beam splitters, number-resolving detectors, heralding. \u2714\n  2. Teleportation via anti-PT BSM overlaps with (1) once you add heralding.  \n  3. The loop network is interesting but harder to cast as a single well-defined Pytheus target.\n\nStep 3: Select idea (1) as most promising:\n  \u2013 It\u2019s a clear entanglement-swapping network (not mere state generation).  \n  \u2013 Focuses on a non-unitary, tunable transformation (the anti-PT filter) rather than just producing a static state.  \n  \u2013 Uses only SPDC pair sources, single-photon ancillas, linear optics and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s design capabilities.  \n  \u2013 Allows a scalable family of experiments by varying the \u201cgain/loss\u201d ratio across the filter and mapping out an exceptional-point transition in entanglement fidelity.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because:\n  \u2013 No prior experiment has demonstrated an exceptional-point phase transition in the fidelity of entanglement swapping by embedding a heralded, post-selected anti-PT non-Hermitian filter into the swapping channel.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus and meets all constraints because:\n  \u2013 The anti-PT filter is implemented purely by linear-optical beam splitters mixing the two modes with single-photon ancillas, followed by post-selection on ancilla clicks.  \n  \u2013 The entanglement-swapping stage is a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement on the filtered modes.  \n  \u2013 No cavities, resonances, dynamic feedback, hyper- or hybrid-entanglement are required\u2014just SPDC, single emitters, beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose to use Pytheus to design a \u201cHeralded Anti-PT Filter in an Entanglement-Swapping Network.\u201d  \nDescription:\n\u2022 Two SPDC pair sources create Bell pairs between modes A\u2013C and B\u2013D.  \n\u2022 Modes C and D enter a heralded non-unitary \u201canti-PT filter\u201d: each is mixed with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter. Specific ancilla detection patterns post-select the non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) on the logical basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}.  \n\u2022 The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM). Successful BSM clicks herald the swapped entanglement between A and B.  \n\u2022 By varying the beam-splitter reflectivity (i.e. the gain/loss ratio \u03b3), one tunes through an exceptional point: below \u03b3c the swapped concurrence drops to zero, above \u03b3c entanglement is recovered.  \n\nSketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2192 Detector A  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2500\u2192 C \u2500[BS r\u2081]\u2500 ancilla\u2081 \u2500[ancilla det]  \nSPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2192 Detector B  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2500\u2192 D \u2500[BS r\u2082]\u2500 ancilla\u2082 \u2500[ancilla det]  \nAfter ancilla heralding, C and D meet at a linear-optical BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters to set:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas).  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [ancilla\u2081, ancilla\u2082].  \n\u2022 removed_connections: forbid direct ancilla\u2192A/B detector paths.  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (outer modes).  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [Det A, Det B] (measure swapped entanglement).  \n\u2022 target_quantum: not a single fixed state\u2014ask Pytheus to realize the conditional non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) followed by a Bell swap.\n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel non-Hermitian network primitive: an anti-PT filter gating entanglement.  \n\u2013 Modular and tunable: scan \u03b3 to map out the exceptional-point behavior.  \n\u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit: SPDC, ancilla photons, beam splitters, number-resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014no forbidden elements."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Superposition of Entanglement Swapping and Purification\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose a fully passive linear\u2010optical chip that employs a single\u2010photon control qubit in state |+\u3009\u2080 to coherently superpose two Bell\u2010pair network operations\u2014entanglement swapping between nodes A and D and parity\u2010check purification of nodes A and B\u2014using only SPDC sources, a control\u2010switch interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors. The device targets the transformation  \n|+\u3009\u2080\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{1,2}\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{3,4} \u2192 |0\u3009\u2080\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,D} + |1\u3009\u2080\u2297\u03c1^{pur}_{A,B},  \nheralded by distinct detection patterns, thereby realizing a new higher\u2010order quantum network primitive for programmable photonic processors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  Integrated Photonic Demonstration of a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router\n\nAbstract:  We implement on a monolithic photonic chip a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router that uses two orthogonally polarized control qubits to coherently select and herald one of four SPDC-based Bell-swap branches in superposition.  By relying only on static PBS/couplers and number-resolving detectors for Bell measurements, our experiment realizes a programmable four-way entanglement-routing primitive without active feed-forward, paving the way toward scalable quantum network fabrics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Amplitude-Damping Entanglement Router Certified by Tomographic Witnesses\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe implement a fully static, loss-controlled quantum router that uses two SPDC Bell-pair sources and an amplitude-damping switch\u2014heralded by ancilla photon clicks\u2014to branch-selectively route entanglement from source A either to node B or C without dynamic feedback or forbidden elements. End-to-end tomography at the chosen node measures the three projector outcomes specified for the selected entanglement witness (the explicit target quantum set), thereby certifying entanglement only in the routed branch.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nSystem Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] Specific ancilla click patterns post-select the non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) on the logical subspace, breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n\u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (BSM). Successful BSM clicks herald entanglement swapped onto photons A and B.  \n\u2022 Scanning the beam-splitter ratio (i.e. tuning \u03b3) drives the system through an exceptional point: below \u03b3_c the swapped entanglement vanishes, above \u03b3_c high-fidelity entanglement reappears.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 A \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 C \u2500[BS r_C]\u2500 ancilla_C \u2500[ancilla det]  \n SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector B  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 D \u2500[BS r_D]\u2500 ancilla_D \u2500[ancilla det]  \n After ancilla heralding, C and D meet at a linear BS-based BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n    description: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n    foldername: \u201cantiPT_ES_switch\u201d  \n    num_anc: 2  \n    single_emitters: [ancilla_C, ancilla_D]  \n    removed_connections: [[ancilla_C\u2192A], [ancilla_C\u2192B], [ancilla_D\u2192A], [ancilla_D\u2192B]]  \n    in_nodes: [A, B]  \n    out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector B]  \n    target_quantum: ['00','11']  (the two-photon coincidence patterns for the swapped Bell pair)  \n    amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (encode the non-unitary gain/loss ratio)  \n    loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True\n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel network primitive: embeds a tunable non-Hermitian anti-PT filter into entanglement swapping and probes its exceptional-point transition in the swapped concurrence.  \n\u2013 Modular and scalable: vary \u03b3 to map out non-Hermitian phase behavior;     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Superposition of Entanglement Swapping and Purification\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose a fully passive linear\u2010optical chip that employs a single\u2010photon control qubit in state |+\u3009\u2080 to coherently superpose two Bell\u2010pair network operations\u2014entanglement swapping between nodes A and D and parity\u2010check purification of nodes A and B\u2014using only SPDC sources, a control\u2010switch interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors. The device targets the transformation  \n|+\u3009\u2080\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{1,2}\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{3,4} \u2192 |0\u3009\u2080\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,D} + |1\u3009\u2080\u2297\u03c1^{pur}_{A,B},  \nheralded by distinct detection patterns, thereby realizing a new higher\u2010order quantum network primitive for programmable photonic processors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. Relying solely on single-emitter photons, probabilistic ancilla, linear optics and number-resolving heralds\u2014without cavities or active feed-forward\u2014this scheme realizes pure quantum-network transformations and is directly extensible to larger gate sets and control registers.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Three-Mode Imaginary\u2010Time Filtering for GHZ\u2083 Entanglement Swapping\n\nAbstract: We present a photonic protocol that embeds the genuinely nonunitary three\u2010mode imaginary\u2010time evolution operator K\u221dexp[\u2013\u03b2(\u03c3\u2093\u2297\u03c3\u1d67\u2297\u03c3_z)] for the target Hamiltonian H\u2083 directly into a three\u2010party GHZ entanglement swap at the relay node. By combining probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancillas, linear\u2010optical elements and heralded post\u2010selection, our scheme teleports a \u201ccooled\u201d GHZ\u2083 state\u2014thereby realizing an irreducible three\u2010body imaginary\u2010time filter within a scalable quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static LOQC Realization of the Entanglement-Assisted (2,3) Quantum Secret Sharing Supermap\n\nAbstract: We experimentally implement the EA(2,3) threshold secret-sharing supermap (target: EA_23_secret_share) as an entanglement-assisted quantum error-correcting code using only passive linear optics, one single-photon emitter, and two pre-shared Bell-pair sources.  By mixing the dealer\u2019s unknown qubit with the Bell halves into three optical share modes via beam splitters and phase shifters, any two players can cooperatively route their modes through a static LOQC decoder and heraldedly reconstruct the dealer\u2019s secret, while individual players gain no information.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. This minimal experiment\u2014requiring only probabilistic photon-pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number-resolving detectors without dynamic feed-forward\u2014demonstrates a novel nonlocal XOR primitive and provides a direct semi-quantum key agreement primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cQuantum Battery\u2013Driven Linear-Optical Entanglement Router\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a purely static linear-optical circuit that uses one ancilla photon as a \u201cquantum battery\u201d to power amplitude-damping Kraus jump operations on one half of three probabilistic Bell pairs, thereby post-selectively swapping entanglement onto exactly one of three remote node pairs via heralded detection. Implemented in the Pytheus static post-selection framework, this battery-powered router converts non-unitary jump channels into a scalable tool for multi-branch entanglement distribution across quantum network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. The successful eight-fold coincidence projects detectors 0\u20133 and 12\u201315 onto the unnormalized target quantum state  \n[\"00000000\", \"00001111\", \"11110000\", \"11111111\", \"00110011\", \"00111100\", \"11000011\", \"11001100\"],  \nheralding a fault-tolerant logical Bell pair between A and D without any feed-forward correction.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. End-to-end tomography at the chosen node measures the three projector outcomes specified for the selected entanglement witness (the explicit target quantum set), thereby certifying entanglement only in the routed branch.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cHeralded Anti-PT Filter in an Entanglement-Swapping Network.\u201d  \n\nExplanation:\nWe take two standard spontaneous-parametric-down\u2010conversion (SPDC) sources producing Bell pairs A\u2013C and B\u2013D. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] Simply renaming \u201cPT\u201d to \u201canti-PT\u201d without introducing a fundamentally new multi-photon exceptional-point effect or a distinct network primitive does not rise to genuine novelty at the PRL level.\n\nAction: reject\n\nAction Input: The non-unitary filter + Bell-swap threshold experiment has already been proposed.     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Experimental genuine tripartite nonlocality in a quantum triangle\n  network\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Optimizing state-discrimination receivers for continuous-variable\n  quantum key distribution over a wiretap channel\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Wavepacket interference of two photons through a beam splitter: from\n  temporal entanglement to wavepacket shaping\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas.
