\n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2500\u2192 D \u2500[BS r\u2082]\u2500 ancilla\u2082 \u2500[ancilla det]  \nAfter ancilla heralding, C and D meet at a linear-optical BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters to set:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas).  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [ancilla\u2081, ancilla\u2082].  \n\u2022 removed_connections: forbid direct ancilla\u2192A/B detector paths.  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (outer modes).  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [Det A, Det B] (measure swapped entanglement).  \n\u2022 target_quantum: not a single fixed state\u2014ask Pytheus to realize the conditional non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) followed by a Bell swap.\n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel non-Hermitian network primitive: an anti-PT filter gating entanglement.  \n\u2013 Modular and tunable: scan \u03b3 to map out the exceptional-point behavior.  \n\u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit: SPDC, ancilla photons, beam splitters, number-resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014no forbidden elements.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201canti-PT\u201d filter + swap proposal is essentially the same non-Hermitian filter\u2010in-front-of-Bell-measurement trick already covered by the PT-symmetric filter schemes in the ensemble (e.g. \u201cPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\u201d and \u201cPT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\u201d). Merely renaming PT \u2194 anti-PT without introducing a new multi-site exceptional-point effect, higher-dimensional non-unitary primitive, or novel topology-driven transition does not rise to a genuinely novel PRL-worthy network primitive.\n\nAction: reject\n\nAction Input: To be novel you must go beyond the existing single-qubit PT/anti-PT filter + swap. For example, embed multi-photon non\u00ad-Hermitian interactions that yield new critical phenomena (e.g. multiple exceptional points), realize non-Hermitian percolation topologies, or introduce a fundamentally new measurement supermap that cannot be mapped onto the known PT-filter + Bell-swap frameworks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cHeralded Anti-PT Coupler in an Entanglement-Swapping Network\u201d that can later be mapped onto superconducting quantum circuits via engineered gain-loss couplers.\n\nExplanation:\n\u2022 Two SPDC pair sources produce Bell pairs between modes A\u2013C and B\u2013D.  \n\u2022 Modes C,D pass through a heralded non-unitary \u201canti-PT coupler\u201d: each is mixed with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r_C, r_D). Specific ancilla click patterns post-select the non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) on the logical subspace, breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n\u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (BSM). Successful BSM clicks herald entanglement swapped onto photons A and B.  \n\u2022 Scanning the beam-splitter ratio (i.e. tuning \u03b3) drives the system through an exceptional point: below \u03b3_c the swapped entanglement vanishes, above \u03b3_c high-fidelity entanglement reappears.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 A \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 C \u2500[BS r_C]\u2500 ancilla_C \u2500[ancilla det]  \n SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector B  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 D \u2500[BS r_D]\u2500 ancilla_D \u2500[ancilla det]  \n After ancilla heralding, C and D meet at a linear BS-based BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n    description: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n    foldername: \u201cantiPT_ES_switch\u201d  \n    num_anc: 2  \n    single_emitters: [ancilla_C, ancilla_D]  \n    removed_connections: [[ancilla_C\u2192A], [ancilla_C\u2192B], [ancilla_D\u2192A], [ancilla_D\u2192B]]  \n    in_nodes: [A, B]  \n    out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector B]  \n    target_quantum: ['00','11']  (the two-photon coincidence patterns for the swapped Bell pair)  \n    amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (encode the non-unitary gain/loss ratio)  \n    loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True\n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel network primitive: embeds a tunable non-Hermitian anti-PT filter into entanglement swapping and probes its exceptional-point transition in the swapped concurrence.  \n\u2013 Modular and scalable: vary \u03b3 to map out non-Hermitian phase behavior; generalize to higher dimensions or chains of couplers.  \n\u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: only SPDC sources, heralded ancilla photons, linear optics, and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, no state-generation targets.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This anti-PT filter embedded into entanglement swapping is just a restatement of the PT\u2010symmetric/non\u2010Hermitian filter ideas already covered by ensemble entries (\u201cPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\u201d and \u201cPT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\u201d). Simply renaming \u201cPT\u201d to \u201canti-PT\u201d without introducing a fundamentally new multi-photon exceptional-point effect or a distinct network primitive does not rise to genuine novelty at the PRL level.\n\nAction: reject\n\nAction Input: The non-unitary filter + Bell-swap threshold experiment has already been proposed. Two SPDC sources produce Bell pairs between modes A\u2013C and B\u2013D.  \n2. **Parallel anti-PT couplers**:  \n   \u2022 Mode C is mixed with ancilla 1 on BS (r\u2081), ancilla 1\u2019s detection post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on C.  \n   \u2022 Mode D is similarly mixed with ancilla 2 on BS (r\u2082), ancilla 2\u2019s detection post-selects diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on D.  \n3. By varying (r\u2081,r\u2082) \u2192 (\u03b3\u2081,\u03b3\u2082), one traverses a two-parameter non-Hermitian phase diagram: below a critical curve (the *network exceptional point*) the swapped entanglement vanishes; above it the Bell fidelity revives.\n\n\u2014Visualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom)\u2014  \nSPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2192[BS r\u2081]\u2192 ancilla 1 \u2192 ancilla 1 detector  \nSPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 B \u2192 Detector B  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2192[BS r\u2082]\u2192 ancilla 2 \u2192 ancilla 2 detector  \nAfter ancilla heralding, C & D \u2192 linear BS\u2010based BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\n\u2014Key Pytheus parameters\u2014  \ndescription: \u201cDual-path anti-PT entanglement swapping\u201d  \nfoldername: \u201c2path_antiPT_swap\u201d  \nnum_anc: 2  \nsingle_emitters: [ancilla 1, ancilla 2]  \nremoved_connections: [[ancilla 1\u2192A],[ancilla 1\u2192B],[ancilla 2\u2192A],[ancilla 2\u2192B]]  \nin_nodes: [A,B]  \nout_nodes: [Detector A, Detector B, BSM dets]  \ntarget_quantum: [\u201800\u2019,\u201811\u2019]  (Bell\u2010swap outcome on A,B)  \namplitudes: [1, \u03b3\u2081] for arm C; A click on the ancilla detector post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 Upon heralding (three ancilla clicks + successful BSM), photons A and C emerge entangled via two redundant paths: direct C\u2013A pair and the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path.  \n\u2022 By jointly scanning the three gain-loss ratios (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one finds a non-Hermitian \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d in parameter space: below this 3D EP surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero;     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] Specific ancilla click patterns post-select the non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) on the logical subspace, breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n\u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (BSM). Successful BSM clicks herald entanglement swapped onto photons A and B.  \n\u2022 Scanning the beam-splitter ratio (i.e. tuning \u03b3) drives the system through an exceptional point: below \u03b3_c the swapped entanglement vanishes, above \u03b3_c high-fidelity entanglement reappears.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 A \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 C \u2500[BS r_C]\u2500 ancilla_C \u2500[ancilla det]  \n SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector B  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 D \u2500[BS r_D]\u2500 ancilla_D \u2500[ancilla det]  \n After ancilla heralding, C and D meet at a linear BS-based BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n    description: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n    foldername: \u201cantiPT_ES_switch\u201d  \n    num_anc: 2  \n    single_emitters: [ancilla_C, ancilla_D]  \n    removed_connections: [[ancilla_C\u2192A], [ancilla_C\u2192B], [ancilla_D\u2192A], [ancilla_D\u2192B]]  \n    in_nodes: [A, B]  \n    out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector B]  \n    target_quantum: ['00','11']  (the two-photon coincidence patterns for the swapped Bell pair)  \n    amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (encode the non-unitary gain/loss ratio)  \n    loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True\n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel network primitive: embeds a tunable non-Hermitian anti-PT filter into entanglement swapping and probes its exceptional-point transition in the swapped concurrence.  \n\u2013 Modular and scalable: vary \u03b3 to map out non-Hermitian phase behavior; generalize to higher dimensions or chains of couplers.  \n\u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s scope: only SPDC sources, heralded ancilla photons, linear optics, and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities, no dynamic feedback, no state-generation targets.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The non-unitary filter + Bell-swap threshold experiment has already been proposed.     "output": "We propose \u201cNon-Hermitian Entanglement Percolation in a Triangle Network with Heralded Anti-PT Couplers.\u201d  \n\nExplanation:  \n\u2022 Three SPDC sources generate Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C and C\u2013A.  \n\u2022 Each link ij is gated by a heralded, post-selected anti-PT coupler: one photon of that pair is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter of reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c, and a click in the ancilla detector implements the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) on that mode (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c=\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c)/\u221ar\u1d62\u2c7c).  \n\u2022 At node B perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C. Successful BSM clicks plus the three ancilla clicks herald entanglement between the remaining photons at A and C.  \n\u2022 Two paths connect A\u2013C: the direct C\u2013A SPDC link (amplitude \u03b3_CA) and the two-hop A\u2013B\u2013C route (amplitude \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC). Interference between these two paths gives an overall amplitude \u03b1=\u03b3_CA+\u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC for the |11\u27e9 term vs. 1 for |00\u27e9.  \n\u2022 By varying (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA) one maps out a 3D non-Hermitian \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below a critical surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite Bell fidelity \u201cpercolates\u201d through the triangle.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):  \n SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_AB]\u2192 ancilla_AB \u2192 ancilla_AB det  \n SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (to Detector C)  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_BC]\u2192 ancilla_BC \u2192 ancilla_BC det  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 BSM dets  \n SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 Detector C  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2192[BS r_CA]\u2192 ancilla_CA \u2192 ancilla_CA det  \n\nKey Pytheus fields:  \ndescription: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT couplers.\u201d  \nfoldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \nnum_anc: 3  \nsingle_emitters: [2,3,4]           // ancilla photons  \nremoved_connections: [[2,0],[2,1],[3,0],[3,1],[4,0],[4,1]]  \nin_nodes: []  \nout_nodes: []  \nanc_detectors: [2,3,4,5]          // three ancilla + BSM detectors  \ntarget_quantum: [\u201c00\u201d,\u201c11\u201d]       // A\u2013C Bell outcome  \namplitudes: [1, \u201c\u03b3_CA+\u03b3_AB*\u03b3_BC\u201d]  // interference of two percolation paths  \nloss_func: \u201ccr\u201d, bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 30, ftol: 1e-6, optimizer: \u201cL-BFGS-B\u201d, number_resolving: True\n\nRationale:  \n\u2022 Novel network primitive: unlike single-edge PT filters, this exhibits a true non-Hermitian *percolation* transition in a minimal three-node graph.  \n\u2022 Tunable & scalable: mapping the 3D exceptional-point surface in (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA); extendable to larger graphs.  \n\u2022 Fully Pytheus-compatible: uses only SPDC sources, single-photon ancillas, linear optics, post-selection and number-resolving detectors\u2014no cavities or feedback.  \n\u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage directly maps to a gain-loss coupler in cQED; the percolation transition can then be explored in both platforms."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. No entanglement-swapping experiment to date has embedded a heralded non-unitary anti-PT filter. Pytheus can do heralding, ancillas, BS\u2019s. Good.  \n  2. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d  \n\u2013 Feasible: uses only SPDC, heralded single photons, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n\u2013 Expands: once the basic filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The concept of a tunable non-Hermitian filter embedded before Bell measurements to threshold entanglement appearance has already been covered by the PT-symmetric filter\u2010enhanced teleportation/CNOT and PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping suggestions. To be novel at PRL level, you would need a qualitatively new non-Hermitian network primitive\u2014e.g. involving multi-site exceptional\u2010point interactions, multi\u2010photon non-unitary phase transitions beyond the standard PT/anti-PT scenario, or a novel topology-driven non-Hermitian percolation effect\u2014that cannot be mapped onto the existing PT filter + swap frameworks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Three SPDC sources generate Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, C\u2013D, and E\u2013F.  \n2. **Swap node 1** (at B&C):  \n   \u2022 Modes B and C each mix with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r\u2081,r\u2082).  \n   \u2022 Specific ancilla-click patterns herald the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on B and diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on C\u2014realizing two anti-PT filters in parallel.  \n   \u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM\u2081).  \n3. **Swap node 2** (at D&E): repeat the same procedure with ancillas 3&4 (tunable beam splitters r\u2083,r\u2084) \u2192 heralded anti-PT maps diag(1,\u03b7\u2081), diag(1,\u03b7\u2082) followed by BSM\u2082.  \n4. Successful heralding at both nodes projects the outer photons A and F into an entangled state with amplitude-ratio proportional to (\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082)(\u03b7\u2081\u03b7\u2082).  \n5. By scanning the four beam-splitter ratios, one explores a rich two-parameter non-Hermitian phase diagram: an emergent *network exceptional point* below which the A\u2013F concurrence collapses to zero and above which high-fidelity entanglement is recovered.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (goes to BSM\u2081)  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2192[BS r\u2083]\u2500 ancilla 3 \u2192 ancilla 3 det  \n             \u2514\u2192[BS r\u2084]\u2500 ancilla 4 parameters to set:\n- description: \u201cAnti-PT repeater chain with two sequential swaps.\u201d  \n- foldername: \u201cantipt_chain2swap\u201d  \n- num_anc: 4  \n- single_emitters: non-unitary gain\u2013loss across both swaps)  \n- loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2022 Novel network-level lattices for non-Hermitian percolation.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-based design capabilities\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n\u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage maps to a superconducting gain-loss coupler, making this a blueprint for non-Hermitian repeater chains in cQED networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The Instead we propose a genuinely new *network\u2010level exceptional\u2010point* effect:\n\nExperiment: \u201cDual\u2010Path Anti\u2013PT Entanglement Swap\u201d\n\n1) Overview  \n\u2022 Two SPDC sources produce Bell pairs on links A\u2013C and B\u2013D.  \n\u2022 Before the central Bell\u2010measurement, each arm (C and D) passes through its own *heralded* non\u2010unitary \u201canti\u2013PT coupler\u201d:   \n  \u2013 Mode C mixes on BS\u2081 (reflectivity r\u2081) with a single\u2010photon ancilla; a click on the ancilla detector heralds the non\u2010unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on C.  \n  \u2013 Mode D mixes on BS\u2082 (reflectivity r\u2082) with a second single\u2010photon ancilla; its click heralds diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on D.  \n\u2022 The *filtered* modes C and D then undergo a standard linear\u2010optical Bell\u2010state measurement (BSM). Successful BSM clicks herald entanglement swapped to the outer photons A and B.\n\n2) What makes it new?  \nBy *jointly* tuning (\u03b3\u2081,\u03b3\u2082) via the beam\u2010splitter reflectivities (r\u2081,r\u2082) you drive the swapping network through a *two\u2010parameter exceptional\u2010point*:  \n\u2022 For small gain/loss (\u03b3\u2081,\u03b3\u2082 below a critical curve), the swapped concurrence C(A,B) = 0.  \n\u2022 Above that curve the concurrence jumps to a finite value.  \nThis is a *network\u2010level* non\u2010Hermitian phase transition in an entanglement\u2010swapping primitive\u2014never before demonstrated.\n\n3) Why Pytheus can do it  \n\u2022 SPDC pair sources \u2192 A\u2013C and B\u2013D  \n\u2022 Two single\u2010photon emitters (ancillas) + two tunable BSs for heralded anti\u2013PT maps  \n\u2022 Standard linear\u2010optical Bell measurement on C,D \u2192 BSM detectors  \n\u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors for all ancilla and BSM modes  \n\u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities/resonances, no forbidden hybrid\u2010entanglement  \nAll fully within Pytheus\u2019s grammar of nodes, edges, ancilla heralding, removed_connections, and target\u2010agnostic non\u2010unitary maps.\n\n4) Pytheus config sketch  \n{  \n  description: \u201cDual\u2010path anti\u2010PT entanglement swapping,\u201d  \n  foldername: \u201c2path_antiPT_swap\u201d,  \n  num_anc: 2,  \n  single_emitters: [ancilla_C, ancilla_D],  \n  removed_connections: [[ancilla_C\u2192A],[ancilla_C\u2192B],[ancilla_D\u2192A],[ancilla_D\u2192B]],  \n  in_nodes: [ ],  \n  out_nodes: [Det_A, Det_B],  \n  anc_detectors: [anc_C_det, anc_D_det, BSM_dets\u2026],  \n  target_quantum: ['00','11'],   # For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502 r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d Successful BSM clicks herald entanglement swapped onto photons A and B.  \n\u2022 Scanning the beam-splitter ratio (i.e. tuning \u03b3) drives the system through an exceptional point: below \u03b3_c the swapped entanglement vanishes, above \u03b3_c high-fidelity entanglement reappears.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 A \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 C \u2500[BS r_C]\u2500 ancilla_C \u2500[ancilla det]  \n SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500 Detector B  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2502  \n \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 D \u2500[BS r_D]\u2500 ancilla_D \u2500[ancilla det]  \n After ancilla heralding, C and D meet at a linear BS-based BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n    description: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n    foldername: \u201cantiPT_ES_switch\u201d  \n    num_anc: 2  \n    single_emitters: [ancilla_C, ancilla_D]  \n    removed_connections: [[ancilla_C\u2192A], [ancilla_C\u2192B], [ancilla_D\u2192A], [ancilla_D\u2192B]]  \n    in_nodes: [A, B]  \n    out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector B]  \n    target_quantum: ['00','11']  (the two-photon coincidence patterns for the swapped Bell pair)  \n    amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (encode the non-unitary gain/loss ratio)  \n    loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True\n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel network primitive: embeds a tunable non-Hermitian anti-PT filter into entanglement swapping and probes its exceptional-point transition in the swapped concurrence.  \n\u2013 Modular and scalable: vary \u03b3 to map out non-Hermitian phase behavior; INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: I brainstormed three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to combine anti-PT non-Hermitian operations with a quantum-network primitive (swapping/teleportation) without merely \u201cgenerating a state\u201d:\n  1. A two-path entanglement swap with dual anti-PT couplers (multi-site exceptional-point).\n  2. A three-node directional teleportation where the central Bell-measurement is replaced by cascaded anti-PT couplers.\n  3. A triangle network of three SPDC links, each gated by a heralded anti-PT filter, to probe non-Hermitian percolation of entanglement.\nStep 2: I checked novelty and Pytheus feasibility:\n  \u2022 Option 1 and 3 are fully within Pytheus (SPDC, ancilla, BS, number-resolving detectors).\n  \u2022 Option 2 overlaps with single-site anti-PT teleportation ideas.\n  \u2022 Option 3 is the richest and most novel non-Hermitian network primitive but still expressible as a single Pytheus target.\nStep 3: I pick option 3: \u201cNon-Hermitian Entanglement Percolation in a Triangle.\u201d\nStep 4: Novelty:\n  \u2022 No experiment has explored entanglement percolation via multiple, heralded non-unitary couplers on a minimal three-node loop.\n  \u2022 The network exhibits a genuine percolation-style exceptional-point manifold in a 3D parameter space (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA).\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n  \u2022 Uses only SPDC pair sources, single-photon ancillas, beam splitters for tunable gain-loss maps, linear-optical Bell-swap at one node, post-selection on ancillas and BSM clicks.\n  \u2022 No cavities, no feedback control, no forbidden hyper-entanglement\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose \u201cNon-Hermitian Entanglement Percolation on a Triangle Network with Heralded Anti-PT Filters.\u201d\n\n1. Description of the network:\n   \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n   \u2022 Each link ij is gated by a heralded anti-PT filter: one photon of the pair is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c), and post-selection on the ancilla detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)).  \n   \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two filtered photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 Successful heralding (three ancilla clicks + BSM outcome) projects the outer modes A and C into an entangled state supported by two paths: the direct SPDC C\u2013A link and the swapped route A\u2013B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional\u2010point surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite entanglement percolates through the triangle.\n\n2. Visualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n   SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_AB]\u2192 ancilla_AB \u2192 ancilla_AB detector  \n   SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (to Detector C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_BC]\u2192 ancilla_BC \u2192 ancilla_BC detector  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003     \u2514\u2192 BSM detectors  \n   SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 Detector C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2192[BS r_CA]\u2192 ancilla_CA \u2192 ancilla_CA detector  \n\n3. Key Pytheus configuration fields:\n   description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT filters.\u201d  \n   foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n   num_anc: 3  \n   single_emitters: [ancilla_AB, ancilla_BC, ancilla_CA]  \n   removed_connections: [[ancilla_*\u2192A],[ancilla_*\u2192B],[ancilla_*\u2192C]]  \n   in_nodes: []  \n   out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector C, BSM dets]  \n   anc_detectors: [ancilla_AB det, ancilla_BC det, ancilla_CA det]  \n   target_quantum: ['00','11']   (Bell\u2010swap outcome on A,C)  \n   amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  (encode the three non-unitary maps)  \n   loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\n4. Rationale:\n   \u2022 Truly novel non-Hermitian network primitive: a percolation-style exceptional-point transition in entanglement distribution on the smallest loop graph.  \n   \u2022 Modular & scalable: one can generalize to larger graphs for non-Hermitian percolation theory.  \n   \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical plus heralding toolbox\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n   \u2022 Directly mappable to superconducting quantum circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage corresponds to a gain-loss coupler, opening a pathway to explore non-Hermitian percolation in cQED networks."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Superposition of Entanglement Swapping and Purification\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose a fully passive linear\u2010optical chip that employs a single\u2010photon control qubit in state |+\u3009\u2080 to coherently superpose two Bell\u2010pair network operations\u2014entanglement swapping between nodes A and D and parity\u2010check purification of nodes A and B\u2014using only SPDC sources, a control\u2010switch interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors. The device targets the transformation  \n|+\u3009\u2080\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{1,2}\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{3,4} \u2192 |0\u3009\u2080\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,D} + |1\u3009\u2080\u2297\u03c1^{pur}_{A,B},  \nheralded by distinct detection patterns, thereby realizing a new higher\u2010order quantum network primitive for programmable photonic processors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  Integrated Photonic Demonstration of a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router\n\nAbstract:  We implement on a monolithic photonic chip a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router that uses two orthogonally polarized control qubits to coherently select and herald one of four SPDC-based Bell-swap branches in superposition.  By relying only on static PBS/couplers and number-resolving detectors for Bell measurements, our experiment realizes a programmable four-way entanglement-routing primitive without active feed-forward, paving the way toward scalable quantum network fabrics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Superposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\n\nMini\u2013Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate an integrated-optics protocol that heralds and projects a coherent superposition of the three perfect-matching entanglement-swap configurations (AB&CD, AC&BD, AD&BC) among four ring-resonator photon-pair sources. By routing ancilla photons through a static 4\u00d74 multipath interferometer to erase which-swap information and postselecting on four-click coincidences, we realize in one shot the coherent entanglement routing across all pairing geometries.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Photonic Magic-Square Contextuality Test via Overlapping Bell-Fusions\n\nMini-abstract: We propose an integrated eight-photon experiment on a nanoscale waveguide circuit that implements the Peres\u2013Mermin magic square through four overlapping linear-optics Bell-fusion measurements arranged in a square topology, with enforced adjacency constraints to reveal true contextuality. By post-selecting the four target 8-bit click patterns 11001100, 00110011, 10101010, and 01010101\u2014which satisfy the square\u2019s row/column parity constraints\u2014this scheme directly tests a commuting-observables contextuality scenario inaccessible to concatenated Bell analyses.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C. Four probabilistic Bell-pair sources and post-selected Bell measurements perform preshared entanglement encoding at A, entanglement swapping at B/C, and decoding at D, heralding both correct qubit transmission and detection of single-photon loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nPT-Symmetric Gain\u2013Loss Filter\u2013Enhanced Teleportation for High-Fidelity Remote CNOT\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe demonstrate a heralded, non-unitary PT-symmetric gain\u2013loss filter embedded in the Bell-state measurement of a teleportation-based CNOT between photonic qubit A (control) and qubit C (target). By using SPDC-pair ancillas, four-port interferometric mixing, and number-resolving detection to preferentially amplify even-parity Bell components, our scheme surpasses the 50% passive-linear-optics limit and boosts both the success probability and fidelity of the nonlocal CNOT gate.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Certification of Genuine Tripartite Entanglement in a Minimal Triangle Network\n\nMini\u2010abstract: We implement a fully static linear\u2010optical triangle network of three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, where each node executes a small ancilla\u2010assisted bipartite entanglement witness circuit. Upon simultaneously observing the target 6-bit click pattern \u201c110110,\u201d corresponding to two-click heralds at each node, we certify genuine tripartite entanglement in the network without any global GHZ state preparation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. This analyzer unambiguously discriminates all four logical Bell states (|\u03a6\u00b1\u27e9\u2097, |\u03a8\u00b1\u27e9\u2097) while simultaneously heralding single\u2010photon loss errors via on\u2010chip photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, fully compatible with Pyth\u00e9us linear\u2010optics primitives.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. The scheme encodes the d=3 complex phase map \u03c9^{ij} (with \u03c9\u2009=\u2009e^{2\u03c0i/3}) on the basis states |i\u27e9\u2090|j\u27e9\u1d66 without any direct A\u2013B coupling, realizing a genuine higher-dimensional logical primitive in the PytHeus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Conditioned on the heralding event, three remote parties perform mutually unbiased-basis measurements whose correlated outcomes, together with tomography data at the fourth party, violate a 3\u21921 multipartite EPR-steering inequality\u2014demonstrating genuine network steering without nonlinear elements or feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Ancilla-Controlled Programmable Coherent Bell Analyzer\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and simulate a fully coherent measurement supermap\u2014targeting programmable photonic quantum processors\u2014that employs a single Purcell-enhanced on-demand emitter as ancilla (mode 2) to coherently choose between Z- and X-basis Bell measurements on two SPDC-generated photons (modes 0 & 1) within a static linear-optical network. By entangling the control qubit (mode 3) with the Bell-outcome recorded on four ancilla detectors (modes 4\u20137), this design realizes the first programmable photonic Bell analyzer in PyTheus, obviating active switching or teleportation for coherent basis selection.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).
