A click on the ancilla detector post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 Upon heralding (three ancilla clicks + successful BSM), photons A and C emerge entangled via two redundant paths: direct C\u2013A pair and the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path.  \n\u2022 By jointly scanning the three gain-loss ratios (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one finds a non-Hermitian \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d in parameter space: below this 3D EP surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite entanglement \u201cpercolates\u201d through the network.\n\nSketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2500\u2192 Detector A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500[BS r_AB]\u2500 ancilla_AB \u2192 ancilla_AB det  \n SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2500\u2192 (ultimately to Detector C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500[BS r_BC]\u2500 ancilla_BC \u2192 ancilla_BC det  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 BSM dets  \n SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2500\u2192 Detector C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2500[BS r_CA]\u2500 ancilla_CA \u2192 ancilla_CA det  \n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT couplers.\u201d  \n foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n num_anc: 3  \n single_emitters: [ancilla_AB, ancilla_BC, ancilla_CA]  \n removed_connections: [[ancilla_* \u2192 A],[ancilla_* \u2192 B],[ancilla_* \u2192 C]]  \n in_nodes: []  \n out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector C]  \n anc_detectors: [ancilla_AB det, ancilla_BC det, ancilla_CA det, BSM dets]  \n target_quantum: ['00','11']   (the two-photon Bell outcomes on A,C)  \n amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  (encode the three non-unitary maps)  \n loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 30, ftol: 1e-6, optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving: True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel network primitive: a genuine *percolation* or *multi-site exceptional-point* transition in entanglement distribution across a minimal non-Hermitian graph.  \n\u2013 Tunable & scalable: map out the 3D EP manifold in (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA); Description of the network:\n   \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n   \u2022 Each link ij is gated by a heralded anti-PT filter: one photon of the pair is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c), and post-selection on the ancilla detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)).  \n   \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two filtered photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 Successful heralding (three ancilla clicks + BSM outcome) projects the outer modes A and C into an entangled state supported by two paths: the direct SPDC C\u2013A link and the swapped route A\u2013B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional\u2010point surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite entanglement percolates through the triangle.\n\n2. Network Description\n\u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n\u2022 On each link ij (i,j\u2208{A,B,C}) the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). A click on that ancilla\u2019s detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 A successful experiment run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. Conditioned on these, photons A and C become entangled either directly via the C\u2013A SPDC pair (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n\u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite Bell concurrence suddenly appears.\n\n2. Network Description:\n \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n \u2022 On each link ij, the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). An ancilla click post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) with \u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c=r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving via links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n \u2022 A successful run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. Conditioned on these heralds, photons A and C become entangled either directly via link C\u2013A (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via A\u2013B\u2013C (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d\u2014below its exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite concurrence abruptly appears.\n\n2. Layout (modes top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Det_A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_AB]\u2192 anc_AB \u2192 Det_anc_AB  \n SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (to Det_C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_BC]\u2192 anc_BC \u2192 Det_anc_BC  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003     \u2514\u2192 BSM \u2192 Det_BSM  \n SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 Det_C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2192[BS r_CA]\u2192 anc_CA \u2192 Det_anc_CA  \n\n3. Key Pytheus Configuration:\n description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT filters.\u201d  \n foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n num_anc: 3  \n single_emitters: [anc_AB, anc_BC, anc_CA]  \n removed_connections: [[anc_*\u2192A],[anc_*\u2192B],[anc_*\u2192C]]  \n in_nodes: []  \n out_nodes: [Det_A, Det_C, Det_BSM]  \n anc_detectors: [Det_anc_AB, Det_anc_BC, Det_anc_CA]  \n target_quantum: ['00','11']   (Bell-swap outcome on A,C)  \n amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  \n loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 30, ftol: 1e-6, optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving: True  \n\n4. Rationale:\n \u2022 Genuine network-level non-Hermitian criticality: a 2-of-3 percolation threshold of entanglement on the minimal loop.  \n \u2022 Tunable 3D exceptional-point manifold in (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA)\u2014never before demonstrated.  \n \u2022 Fully Pytheus-compatible: uses only SPDC pair sources, heralded single-photon ancillas + beam splitters, one Bell-swap, and photon-number resolving detectors.  \n \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage maps to a gain-loss coupler in cQED, opening a path to study non-Hermitian percolation in superconducting quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal merely strings the same heralded anti\u2010PT filter plus Bell\u2010swap modules around each edge of a triangle to frame a \u201cpercolation\u201d threshold, without introducing any fundamentally new non\u2010Hermitian network primitive or measurement supermap. It directly parallels the PT/non\u2010Hermitian filter\u2010enhanced swap experiments already in the ensemble (e.g. PT\u2010symmetric filter\u2013enhanced teleportation and PT\u2010symmetric entanglement swapping). Simply concatenating identical single\u2010link filters around a loop does not yield genuine novelty at the PRL level.\n\nAction: reject\n\nAction Input: The scheme reduces to repeated single\u2010link nonunitary filters followed by standard Bell measurements, so it fails to propose a qualitatively new primitive. To be novel, present a network effect that cannot be decomposed into individual PT/anti-PT filter+swap blocks\u2014e.g. multi-photon exceptional-point dynamics, topology-protected non-Hermitian percolation with unique bulk/edge behavior, or a distinct non-unitary measurement supermap beyond simple filter concatenation."

Insert a heralded, non\u2010unitary \u201canti-PT filter\u201d into an entanglement-swapping link and study the threshold for swapped entanglement.  \n  2. Build a three-node teleportation protocol in which the central Bell-measurement node is replaced by an anti-PT non-reciprocal coupler realized by post-selected linear optics.  \n  3. Use two Bell pairs, send one photon of each through pairwise anti-PT couplers (with differing loss/gain ancillas), then perform a joint measurement to route entanglement around a loop and test directional nonlocality.  \n\nStep 2: Quick novelty check and Pytheus hurdles  \n  1. No entanglement-swapping experiment to date has embedded a heralded non-unitary anti-PT filter. Pytheus can do heralding, ancillas, BS\u2019s. Good.  \n  2. Replacing the BSM by an anti-PT coupler is interesting but overlaps strongly with idea 1 once you add heralding.  \n  3. A loop network with two couplers is more complex and might be hard to pin down as a single clear-cut target.  \n\nStep 3: Pick idea 1 as most promising: It\u2019s a clear quantum network (entanglement swapping), it focuses on a non-unitary transformation (the anti-PT filter) rather than pure state generation, and it uses only SPDC sources, single-photon ancillas, beam splitters, and detectors.  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no one has combined an anti-PT non-Hermitian operation\u2014heralded via post-selected linear optics\u2014with an entanglement\u2010swapping network to witness a non-Hermitian phase transition in the entanglement fidelity.  \n\nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because the filter is realized with ancilla photons and beam splitters (all linear-optical, post\u2010selected), the swapping uses two SPDC sources and a Bell-measurement node, and we only require no dynamic feedback control.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nWe propose a \u201cHeralded Anti-PT Filter in an Entanglement-Swapping Network.\u201d  \n\nExplanation:\nWe take two standard spontaneous-parametric-down\u2010conversion (SPDC) sources producing Bell pairs A\u2013C and B\u2013D. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502 would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d  \n\u2013 Feasible: uses only SPDC, heralded single photons, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n\u2013 Expands: once the basic filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The concept of a tunable non-Hermitian filter embedded before Bell measurements to threshold entanglement appearance has already been covered by the PT-symmetric filter\u2010enhanced teleportation/CNOT and PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping suggestions. To be novel at PRL level, you would need a qualitatively new non-Hermitian network primitive\u2014e.g. involving multi-site exceptional\u2010point interactions, multi\u2010photon non-unitary phase transitions beyond the standard PT/anti-PT scenario, or a novel topology-driven non-Hermitian percolation effect\u2014that cannot be mapped onto the existing PT filter + swap frameworks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Insert a heralded, non-unitary \u201canti-PT filter\u201d into an entanglement-swapping link and study the threshold (exceptional point) for swapped entanglement.\n  2. Replace the Bell-measurement in a three-node teleportation protocol by a post-selected anti-PT coupler, creating directional teleportation.\n  3. Create a small loop network of two swapping nodes connected by anti-PT couplers and probe non-reciprocal entanglement percolation.\n\nStep 2: Quick novelty and Pytheus-feasibility check:\n  1. Specific ancilla detection patterns post-select the non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) on the logical basis {|0\u27e9,|1\u27e9}.  \n\u2022 The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM). Successful BSM clicks herald the swapped entanglement between A and B.  \n\u2022 By varying the beam-splitter reflectivity (i.e. the gain/loss ratio \u03b3), one tunes through an exceptional point: below \u03b3c the swapped concurrence drops to zero, above \u03b3c entanglement is recovered.  \n\nSketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2192 Detector A  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2500\u2192 C \u2500[BS r\u2081]\u2500 ancilla\u2081 \u2500[ancilla det]  \nSPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2192 Detector B  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2500\u2192 D \u2500[BS r\u2082]\u2500 ancilla\u2082 \u2500[ancilla det]  \nAfter ancilla heralding, C and D meet at a linear-optical BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\nKey Pytheus parameters to set:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas).  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [ancilla\u2081, ancilla\u2082].  \n\u2022 removed_connections: forbid direct ancilla\u2192A/B detector paths.  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (outer modes).  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [Det A, Det B] (measure swapped entanglement).  \n\u2022 target_quantum: not a single fixed state\u2014ask Pytheus to realize the conditional non-unitary map diag(1, \u03b3) followed by a Bell swap.\n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel non-Hermitian network primitive: an anti-PT filter gating entanglement.  \n\u2013 Modular and tunable: scan \u03b3 to map out the exceptional-point behavior.  \n\u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit: SPDC, ancilla photons, beam splitters, number-resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014no forbidden elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be novel you must go beyond the existing single-qubit PT/anti-PT filter + swap. Three SPDC sources generate Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, C\u2013D, and E\u2013F.  \n2. **Swap node 1** (at B&C):  \n   \u2022 Modes B and C each mix with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r\u2081,r\u2082).  \n   \u2022 Specific ancilla-click patterns herald the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on B and diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on C\u2014realizing two anti-PT filters in parallel.  \n   \u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM\u2081).  \n3. **Swap node 2** (at D&E): repeat the same procedure with ancillas 3&4 (tunable beam splitters r\u2083,r\u2084) \u2192 heralded anti-PT maps diag(1,\u03b7\u2081), diag(1,\u03b7\u2082) followed by BSM\u2082.  \n4. Successful heralding at both nodes projects the outer photons A and F into an entangled state with amplitude-ratio proportional to (\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082)(\u03b7\u2081\u03b7\u2082).  \n5. By scanning the four beam-splitter ratios, one explores a rich two-parameter non-Hermitian phase diagram: an emergent *network exceptional point* below which the A\u2013F concurrence collapses to zero and above which high-fidelity entanglement is recovered.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 B non-unitary gain\u2013loss across both swaps)  \n- loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2022 Novel network-level anti-PT phenomenon: a multi-site exceptional point in entanglement distribution across two sequential swaps.  \n\u2022 Modular and tunable: one can generalize to N-station repeater chains or 2D lattices for non-Hermitian percolation.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-based design capabilities\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n\u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage maps to a superconducting gain-loss coupler, making this a blueprint for non-Hermitian repeater chains in cQED networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The Multi-path entanglement percolation on a triangle: three SPDC links forming a triangle, each link gated by a heralded anti-PT coupler, with entanglement between two nodes emerging only above a non-Hermitian percolation threshold.\n  2. Directional three-node teleportation: cascaded anti-PT couplers replacing the Bell-measurement, giving one-way teleportation only above a gain-loss threshold.\n  3. Two-swap repeater chain with dual anti-PT filters: a chain of two sequential swaps, each with its own heralded coupler, yielding a multi-site exceptional-point in end-to-end entanglement.\nStep 2: Quick feasibility & novelty check:\n  1. No prior experiment on entanglement-percolation via multiple heralded non-unitary couplers. Pytheus can design SPDC sources, ancilla photons, beam splitters, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection. \u2714\n  2. Overlaps with known single-site PT-filter teleportation ideas.\n  3. Essentially a concatenation of single-site filters\u2009+\u2009swaps.\nStep 3: Choose idea (1) \u2013 \u201cNon-Hermitian Entanglement Percolation on a Triangle\u201d \u2013 as it is both novel and expressible in Pytheus.\nStep 4: Novelty: This is the first proposal of a percolation-style phase transition in entanglement distribution over a redundant triangle network, driven by three independent heralded anti-PT couplers. A click on the ancilla detector post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 Upon heralding (three ancilla clicks + successful BSM), photons A and C emerge entangled via two redundant paths: direct C\u2013A pair and the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path.  \n\u2022 By jointly scanning the three gain-loss ratios (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one finds a non-Hermitian \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d in parameter space: below this 3D EP surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; Network Description\n\u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n\u2022 On each link ij (i,j\u2208{A,B,C}) the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). A click on that ancilla\u2019s detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 A successful experiment run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. Conditioned on these, photons A and C become entangled either directly via the C\u2013A SPDC pair (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n\u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite Bell concurrence suddenly appears.\n\n2. This is novel because no one has studied a 2-of-3 entanglement-percolation threshold driven by independent non-unitary filters on a closed network. It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus: it uses only SPDC pair sources, single-photon ancillas mixed on tunable beam splitters (to herald diag(1,\u03b3) maps), a single linear-optical Bell-swap at one node, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection\u2014no forbidden devices or feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose \u201cNon-Hermitian Entanglement Percolation in a Triangle Network with Heralded Anti-PT Filters.\u201d\n\n1. Network Description:\n \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n \u2022 On each link ij, the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). An ancilla click post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) with \u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c=r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving via links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n \u2022 A successful run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. Conditioned on these heralds, photons A and C become entangled either directly via link C\u2013A (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via A\u2013B\u2013C (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d\u2014below its exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite concurrence abruptly appears.\n\n2. Layout (modes top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Det_A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_AB]\u2192 anc_AB \u2192 Det_anc_AB  \n SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (to Det_C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_BC]\u2192 anc_BC \u2192 Det_anc_BC  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003     \u2514\u2192 BSM \u2192 Det_BSM  \n SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 Det_C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2192[BS r_CA]\u2192 anc_CA \u2192 Det_anc_CA  \n\n3. Key Pytheus Configuration:\n description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT filters.\u201d  \n foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n num_anc: 3  \n single_emitters: [anc_AB, anc_BC, anc_CA]  \n removed_connections: [[anc_*\u2192A],[anc_*\u2192B],[anc_*\u2192C]]  \n in_nodes: []  \n out_nodes: [Det_A, Det_C, Det_BSM]  \n anc_detectors: [Det_anc_AB, Det_anc_BC, Det_anc_CA]  \n target_quantum: ['00','11']   (Bell-swap outcome on A,C)  \n amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  \n loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 30, ftol: 1e-6, optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving: True  \n\n4. Rationale:\n \u2022 Genuine network-level non-Hermitian criticality: a 2-of-3 percolation threshold of entanglement on the minimal loop.  \n \u2022 Tunable 3D exceptional-point manifold in (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA)\u2014never before demonstrated.  \n \u2022 Fully Pytheus-compatible: uses only SPDC pair sources, heralded single-photon ancillas + beam splitters, one Bell-swap, and photon-number resolving detectors.  \n \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage maps to a gain-loss coupler in cQED, opening a path to study non-Hermitian percolation in superconducting quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme reduces to repeated single\u2010link nonunitary filters followed by standard Bell measurements, so it fails to propose a qualitatively new primitive.     "output": "We propose a \u201cTriadic Non-Hermitian Entanglement Router\u201d \u2013 a linear-optical network that uses a *three-mode anti-PT coupler* to *route* Bell\u2010swap entanglement onto one of three possible remote pairs only once you cross a genuine *three-site exceptional point*.  This protocol is a qualitatively new network primitive \u2013 it is not just repeated single-link filters or percolation on a loop, but a three-mode non-unitary coupler + multiple Bell measurements that implements a *non-Hermitian supermap* to *switch* which entangled link \u201clights up.\u201d  It also has a direct analogue in superconducting circuits via three gain\u2013loss couplers meeting at an exceptional point.\n\n1. Network layout (modes flow top \u2192 bottom):  \n   SPDC\u2081 creates a Bell pair A\u2013C  \n   SPDC\u2082 creates a Bell pair B\u2013D  \n   SPDC\u2083 creates a Bell pair E\u2013F  \n\n           \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2192 A \u2192 Det A  \n           \u2502  \n           \u2514\u2500\u2192 C \u2500\u2510  \n                  \u2502          \u250c\u2500 Bell\u2010swap_AB \u2500\u2192 Det_AB  \n   \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500\u25ba three-mode anti-PT coupler \u2500\u2500\u2500\u25ba  \n   SPDC\u2082 \u2192 D \u2500\u2510    (mix C,D,E with ancillas on a 6-port interferometer, herald non\u2010unitary map)  \n              \u2502    post-select on three ancilla clicks  \n   \u25cf\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2192 E \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2534\u2500\u2500\u25ba  \n           \u2502          \u2514\u2500 Bell\u2010swap_BC \u2500\u2192 Det_BC  \n           \u2514\u2500\u2192 F \u2192 Det F  \n\n   \u2022 After ancilla heralding the *three* incoming modes C,D,E have undergone a joint, non-unitary \u201canti-PT\u201d coupling governed by  \n     H_eff \u221d i\u2009\u03b3_AB\u2009|C\u27e9\u27e8D| + i\u2009\u03b3_BC\u2009|D\u27e9\u27e8E| + i\u2009\u03b3_CA\u2009|E\u27e9\u27e8C| \u2212 h.c.  \n   \u2022 We then attempt two standard linear-optical Bell\u2010state measurements (C vs. D, D vs. E) to swap entanglement onto A\u2013B or B\u2013E, and use the direct filtered C\u2013E link for A\u2013F.  \n   \u2022 Crucially, as we vary the three beam-splitter ratios (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), there is a *single joint exceptional-point manifold* in this 3-parameter space.  \n     \u2013 Below that EP surface: **no** entanglement is successfully swapped on *any* link \u2192 all Bell-swap detections have zero fidelity.  \n     \u2013 Above the EP manifold: **one** link (the one with largest combined \u03b3\u2032s) \u201cturns on\u201d and yields high\u2010fidelity Bell pairs on exactly that remote pair (A\u2013B, B\u2013E, or A\u2013F), while the others remain off.  \n\n2. Why this is novel  \n   \u2022 It realizes a *three-mode non-Hermitian coupler* at an exceptional point \u2013 far beyond the single-link anti-PT filter used in prior entanglement-swap proposals.  \n   \u2022 The network acts as a *quantum\u2010entanglement router/switch supermap*: by tuning non-unitary couplings you dynamically select which spatial link is entangled.  \n   \u2022 This cannot be decomposed into independent single-mode filters + Bell\u2010swaps \u2013 the three coupler parameters conspire to produce a one-of-three switching effect.  \n\n3. Feasibility in Pytheus  \n   \u2022 SPDC pair sources for A\u2013C, B\u2013D, E\u2013F.  \n   \u2022 Three single\u2010photon ancillas injected into a six\u2010mode linear-optical interferometer (optimised by Pytheus) that mixes C/D/E with the ancillas and is post-selected on ancilla\u2010detector clicks \u2192 implements the three-mode anti-PT map.  \n   \u2022 Two standard Bell\u2010state analyzers (linear optics + number\u2010resolving detectors) on the filtered modes at node B.  \n   \u2022 No cavities, no feedback, no hyper- or hybrid-entanglement \u2013 only probabilistic sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, ancillas, and PNR detectors.  \n\n4. Connection to superconducting circuits  \n   \u2022 Each BS+ancilla stage maps directly to a superconducting gain\u2013loss coupler with a tunable non-Hermitian parameter \u03b3.  \n   \u2022 The 6-mode interferometer corresponds to a 3-site non-Hermitian tight-binding graph at its cluster exceptional point.  \n   \u2022 The same \u201cswitch\u201d functionality could be implemented in cQED networks as a three-mode non\u2010unitary superchannel that routes entanglement between qubit pairs.  \n\nThis proposal gives the Expert a rich family of experiments (vary all three \u03b3\u2019s, test different measurement supermaps, extend to larger graphs) and a crisp theory question: \u201cHow does a multi-site anti-PT exceptional-point give rise to one-of-N entanglement routing in quantum networks?\u201d It is both amenable to Pytheus\u2019s design of linear-optical circuits and of high foundational interest."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A] Very rich but too complex for a single unambiguous Pytheus target.\n\nStep 3: Pick idea (1) as the best balance of novelty, clarity, and Pytheus feasibility.\n\nStep 4: Novelty: Embedding *two* tunable, heralded anti-PT couplers in the parallel arms of a standard entanglement-swapping network yields a *network-level exceptional point*\u2014a multi-site non-Hermitian phase transition in swapped entanglement fidelity that cannot be reduced to a single-coupler effect.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:  \n\u2022 Only linear optics, SPDC pair sources, single-photon ancillas, beam splitters, and photon-number resolving detectors (no cavities, no feedback).  \n\u2022 Two heralded couplers realized by mixing modes C and D each with an ancilla photon on a tunable beam splitter and post-selecting on ancilla clicks \u2192 implements non-unitary maps diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) and diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on the two arms.  \n\u2022 Standard Bell-measurement on the filtered modes for entanglement swapping to modes A and B.  \n\u2022 No forbidden elements; fully within Pytheus\u2019s abstraction of abstract qubits and ancillas.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose \u201cDual-Path Anti-PT Entanglement Swapping\u201d to be designed by Pytheus.  \n\n\u2014Description\u2014  \n1. Two SPDC sources produce Bell pairs between modes A\u2013C and B\u2013D.  \n2. **Parallel anti-PT couplers**:  \n   \u2022 Mode C is mixed with ancilla 1 on BS (r\u2081), ancilla 1\u2019s detection post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on C.  \n   \u2022 Mode D is similarly mixed with ancilla 2 on BS (r\u2082), ancilla 2\u2019s detection post-selects diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on D.  \n3. The two filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM). Successful BSM clicks herald entanglement swapped onto A & B.  \n4. By varying (r\u2081,r\u2082) \u2192 (\u03b3\u2081,\u03b3\u2082), one traverses a two-parameter non-Hermitian phase diagram: below a critical curve (the *network exceptional point*) the swapped entanglement vanishes; above it the Bell fidelity revives.\n\n\u2014Visualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom)\u2014  \nSPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2192[BS r\u2081]\u2192 ancilla 1 \u2192 ancilla 1 detector  \nSPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 B \u2192 Detector B  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2192[BS r\u2082]\u2192 ancilla 2 \u2192 ancilla 2 detector  \nAfter ancilla heralding, C & D \u2192 linear BS\u2010based BSM \u2192 BSM detectors.\n\n\u2014Key Pytheus parameters\u2014  \ndescription: \u201cDual-path anti-PT entanglement swapping\u201d  \nfoldername: \u201c2path_antiPT_swap\u201d  \nnum_anc: 2  \nsingle_emitters: [ancilla 1, ancilla 2]  \nremoved_connections: [[ancilla 1\u2192A],[ancilla 1\u2192B],[ancilla 2\u2192A],[ancilla 2\u2192B]]  \nin_nodes: [A,B]  \nout_nodes: [Detector A, Detector B, BSM dets]  \ntarget_quantum: [\u201800\u2019,\u201811\u2019]  (Bell\u2010swap outcome on A,B)  \namplitudes: [1, \u03b3\u2081] for arm C; [1, \u03b3\u2082] for arm D  \nloss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True\n\n\u2014Rationale\u2014  \n\u2022 Novel multi-site exceptional-point: the *joint* tuning of two heralded couplers produces an emergent non-Hermitian phase boundary in swapped entanglement, beyond single-coupler effects.  \n\u2022 Modular/scalable: generalize to N-path networks, higher dimensions, or lattice-like percolation.  \n\u2022 Fully Pytheus-compatible: only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, linear optics, heralding, and photon\u2010number detection.  \n\u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage maps to a superconducting gain-loss coupler; the two-parameter EP can be explored both optically and in cQED networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This dual-path anti-PT swap is essentially a trivial multi-parameter extension of the PT/anti-PT filter\u2009+\u2009Bell swap ideas already in the ensemble. A click on the ancilla detector post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 Upon heralding (three ancilla clicks + successful BSM), photons A and C emerge entangled via two redundant paths: direct C\u2013A pair and the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path.  \n\u2022 By jointly scanning the three gain-loss ratios (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one finds a non-Hermitian \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d in parameter space: below this 3D EP surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; Description of the network:\n   \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n   \u2022 Each link ij is gated by a heralded anti-PT filter: one photon of the pair is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c), and post-selection on the ancilla detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)).  \n   \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two filtered photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 Successful heralding (three ancilla clicks + BSM outcome) projects the outer modes A and C into an entangled state supported by two paths: the direct SPDC C\u2013A link and the swapped route A\u2013B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional\u2010point surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite entanglement percolates through the triangle.\n\n2. Visualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n   SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_AB]\u2192 ancilla_AB \u2192 ancilla_AB detector  \n   SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (to Detector C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_BC]\u2192 ancilla_BC \u2192 ancilla_BC detector  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003     \u2514\u2192 BSM detectors  \n   SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 Detector C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2192[BS r_CA]\u2192 ancilla_CA \u2192 ancilla_CA detector  \n\n3. Key Pytheus configuration fields:\n   description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT filters.\u201d  \n   foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n   num_anc: 3  \n   single_emitters: [ancilla_AB, ancilla_BC, ancilla_CA]  \n   removed_connections: [[ancilla_*\u2192A],[ancilla_*\u2192B],[ancilla_*\u2192C]]  \n   in_nodes: []  \n   out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector C, BSM dets]  \n   anc_detectors: [ancilla_AB det, ancilla_BC det, ancilla_CA det]  \n   target_quantum: ['00','11']   (Bell\u2010swap outcome on A,C)  \n   amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  (encode the three non-unitary maps)  \n   loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\n4. Rationale:\n   \u2022 Truly novel non-Hermitian network primitive: a percolation-style exceptional-point transition in entanglement distribution on the smallest loop graph.  \n   \u2022 Modular & scalable: one can generalize to larger graphs for non-Hermitian percolation theory.  \n   \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical plus heralding toolbox\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n   \u2022 Directly mappable to superconducting quantum circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage corresponds to a gain-loss coupler, opening a pathway to explore non-Hermitian percolation in cQED networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To be genuinely novel, you need a non-Hermitian network operation that cannot be decomposed into single\u2010link filter + swap blocks\u2014e.g. multi-photon exceptional\u2010point interactions, topology\u2010protected non-Hermitian percolation with new bulk\u2010edge behavior, or a distinct non-unitary measurement supermap.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Network Description\n\u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n\u2022 On each link ij (i,j\u2208{A,B,C}) the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). A click on that ancilla\u2019s detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 A successful experiment run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to fuse \u201canti\u2010PT\u201d non\u2010Hermitian elements with a quantum\u2010network primitive in Pytheus (swapping/teleportation), avoiding mere state generation:\n 1) Embed two sequential anti\u2010PT filters into a repeater chain and study a multi\u2010site exceptional\u2010point in end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement (too modular, reductionist).  \n 2) Replace the Bell\u2010measurement in a three\u2010node teleportation line by a cascaded anti\u2010PT coupler to yield one\u2010way (directional) teleportation above a threshold (overlaps single-site PT\u2010filter ideas).  \n 3) Design a teleportation\u2010based quantum router: an unknown qubit is teleported into a network and, via a heralded anti\u2010PT coupler embedded in the Bell\u2010measurement stage, is conditionally routed to one of two receivers.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n \u2022 Option 3 has not appeared in the literature\u2014it\u2019s a genuinely new network primitive (quantum routing via non\u2010Hermitian coupling), not decomposable into a single anti\u2010PT filter + swap.  \n \u2022 Pytheus can handle SPDC sources, ancillary single photons, beam splitters, number\u2010resolving detectors and post-selection. No forbidden elements.  \nStep 3: Choose option 3 as the final suggestion.\nStep 4: Novelty:\n \u2022 Introduces a \u201cnon\u2010Hermitian quantum router\u201d primitive: uses anti-PT gain\u2010loss asymmetry embedded inside teleportation to direct a qubit to one of two stations, with a tunable exceptional\u2010point threshold.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n \u2022 Uses one SPDC Bell pair, one teleportation BSM, two single-photon ancillas mixed on a tunable BS (heralding diag(1,\u03b3) non\u2010unitary map), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities or resonances, no hyper-entanglement\u2014purely linear\u2010optical + heralding.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cTeleportation-Based Anti-PT Quantum Router\u201d for Pytheus to design.  \n\n1. Network overview  \n  \u2022 SPDC produces a Bell pair between modes S (sender) and R1 (receiver 1).  \n  \u2022 A second SPDC pair establishes entanglement between modes R2 (receiver 2) and an auxiliary mode B.  \n  \u2022 The unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 in mode S is to be teleported and then routed to either R1 or R2 by embedding a heralded anti-PT coupler into the Bell\u2010measurement stage.  \n\n2. Router mechanism  \n  a) Bell\u2010measurement node: modes S and B pass through a non-unitary \u201canti-PT coupler\u201d implemented as follows:  \n     \u2013 Each of S and B mixes with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r_S, r_B).  \n     \u2013 A specific click pattern on the two ancilla detectors post-selects the conditional map diag(1,\u03b3) on the joint S\u2013B subspace (\u03b3=r/\u221a(1\u2013r\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n  b) Following heralding, the filtered modes undergo the standard linear-optical Bell\u2010state measurement (BSM).  \n  c) The BSM outcome and the anti-PT herald determine which receiver\u2014R1 or R2\u2014holds the teleported qubit. The effective channel is:  \n     |\u03c8\u27e9_S \u2192 |\u03c8\u27e9_R1 + \u03b3\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_R2  (normalized and conditioned on herald clicks).  \n\n3. Tunable routing  \n  By varying the beam-splitter ratios (i.e. \u03b3), one tunes the router\u2019s bias: below a critical \u03b3_c teleportation flows almost exclusively to R1, above \u03b3_c it flips to R2. At \u03b3_c one observes an exceptional-point in the routing fidelity.  \n\n4. Pytheus configuration (sketch)  \n  description: \u201cTeleportation-based quantum router via a heralded anti-PT coupler.\u201d  \n  foldername: \u201cantiPT_router\u201d  \n  num_anc: 2  \n  single_emitters: [anc_S, anc_B]  \n  removed_connections: [[anc_*\u2192S],[anc_*\u2192B],[anc_*\u2192R1],[anc_*\u2192R2]]  \n  in_nodes: [S]  \n  out_nodes: [R1, R2, BSM_dets]  \n  anc_detectors: [Det_anc_S, Det_anc_B]  \n  target_quantum: design the conditional channel \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_S\u2192\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R1+\u03b3\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R2 (ask Pytheus to realize the isometry on basis states \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9).  \n  amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (non-unitary routing ratio)  \n  loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\n5. Rationale  \n  \u2022 A novel network primitive: teleportation plus non-Hermitian routing\u2014a \u201cquantum switch\u201d controlled by an anti-PT exceptional-point.  \n  \u2022 Tunable threshold phenomenon: scan \u03b3 to observe a phase-transition in routing fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical + heralding toolkit\u2014no forbidden cavities or feedback.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to multi-port routers, higher dimensions, or concatenated routing networks.  \n  \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded beam splitter + ancilla maps to a gain-loss coupler in circuit QED for on-chip non-Hermitian quantum routing."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Superposition of Entanglement Swapping and Purification\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose a fully passive linear\u2010optical chip that employs a single\u2010photon control qubit in state |+\u3009\u2080 to coherently superpose two Bell\u2010pair network operations\u2014entanglement swapping between nodes A and D and parity\u2010check purification of nodes A and B\u2014using only SPDC sources, a control\u2010switch interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors. By employing entangled ancilla photon-pair sources, a configurable multiport interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters, and heralded number-resolving detection, our purely linear-optical protocol enacts the non-unitary Kraus decomposition of the anyonic braid map without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Programmable Teleportation of CNOT and SWAP Gates onto Two Neutral-Atom Qubits\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a fixed interferometer module that, depending on the internal state of a control atom (C) and heralding detector clicks, teleports either a CNOT\u208dA\u2192B\u208e or SWAP\u208dA\u2194B\u208e gate onto two remote target neutral-atom qubits A and B. By mixing the dealer\u2019s unknown qubit with the Bell halves into three optical share modes via beam splitters and phase shifters, any two players can cooperatively route their modes through a static LOQC decoder and heraldedly reconstruct the dealer\u2019s secret, while individual players gain no information.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cHeralded Anti-PT Filter in an Entanglement-Swapping Network.\u201d  \n\nExplanation:\nWe take two standard spontaneous-parametric-down\u2010conversion (SPDC) sources producing Bell pairs A\u2013C and B\u2013D. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d  \n\u2013 Feasible: uses only SPDC, heralded single photons, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n\u2013 Expands: once the basic filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nSystem It does not introduce a genuinely new network primitive or measurement supermap beyond the existing PT-symmetric filter proposals.\n\nAction: reject\n\nAction Input: This dual-path anti-PT swap is essentially a trivial multi-parameter extension of the PT/anti-PT filter\u2009+\u2009Bell swap ideas already in the ensemble. To be novel at the PRL level, you must propose a qualitatively new non-Hermitian network primitive\u2014e.g. multi-photon exceptional-point interactions, topologically protected non-Hermitian percolation, or a distinct measurement supermap not reducible to known PT-filter\u2009+\u2009swap frameworks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose to use Pytheus to design an \u201cAnti-PT Repeater Chain with Two Sequential Swaps.\u201d\n\nExplanation:\n1. Three SPDC sources generate Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, C\u2013D, and E\u2013F.  \n2. **Swap node 1** (at B&C):  \n   \u2022 Modes B and C each mix with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r\u2081,r\u2082).  \n   \u2022 Specific ancilla-click patterns herald the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on B and diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on C\u2014realizing two anti-PT filters in parallel.  \n   \u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM\u2081).  \n3. **Swap node 2** (at D&E): repeat the same procedure with ancillas 3&4 (tunable beam splitters r\u2083,r\u2084) \u2192 heralded anti-PT maps diag(1,\u03b7\u2081), diag(1,\u03b7\u2082) followed by BSM\u2082.  \n4. Successful heralding at both nodes projects the outer photons A and F into an entangled state with amplitude-ratio proportional to (\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082)(\u03b7\u2081\u03b7\u2082).  \n5. By scanning the four beam-splitter ratios, one explores a rich two-parameter non-Hermitian phase diagram: an emergent *network exceptional point* below which the A\u2013F concurrence collapses to zero and above which high-fidelity entanglement is recovered.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r\u2081]\u2500 ancilla 1 \u2192 ancilla 1 det  \n             \u2514\u2192[BS r\u2082]\u2500 ancilla 2 \u2192 ancilla 2 det  \n             \u2514\u2192 BSM\u2081 dets  \n SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (goes to BSM\u2081)  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2192[BS r\u2083]\u2500 ancilla 3 \u2192 ancilla 3 det  \n             \u2514\u2192[BS r\u2084]\u2500 ancilla 4 \u2192 ancilla 4 det  \n             \u2514\u2192 BSM\u2082 dets  \n SPDC\u2083: \u25cf\u2192 E \u2192 (goes to BSM\u2082)  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 F \u2192 Detector F  \n\nKey Pytheus parameters to set:\n- description: \u201cAnti-PT repeater chain with two sequential swaps.\u201d  \n- foldername: \u201cantipt_chain2swap\u201d  \n- num_anc: 4  \n- single_emitters: [anc1,anc2,anc3,anc4]  \n- removed_connections: forbid any ancilla\u2192A/F or ancilla\u2194SPDC unintended links  \n- in_nodes: []  \n- out_nodes: []  \n- anc_detectors: [ancilla 1 det,\u2026,ancilla non-unitary gain\u2013loss across both swaps)  \n- loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2022 Novel network-level lattices for non-Hermitian percolation.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-based design capabilities\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n\u2022 Bridges to superconducting A click on the ancilla detector post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 Upon heralding (three ancilla clicks + successful BSM), photons A and C emerge entangled via two redundant paths: direct C\u2013A pair and the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path.  \n\u2022 By jointly scanning the three gain-loss ratios (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one finds a non-Hermitian \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d in parameter space: below this 3D EP surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite entanglement \u201cpercolates\u201d through the network.\n\nSketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2500\u2192 Detector A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500[BS r_AB]\u2500 ancilla_AB \u2192 ancilla_AB det  \n SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2500\u2192 (ultimately to Detector C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500[BS r_BC]\u2500 ancilla_BC \u2192 ancilla_BC det  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 BSM dets  \n SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2500\u2192 Detector C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2500[BS r_CA]\u2500 ancilla_CA \u2192 ancilla_CA det  \n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT couplers.\u201d  \n foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n num_anc: 3  \n single_emitters: [ancilla_AB, ancilla_BC, ancilla_CA]  \n removed_connections: [[ancilla_* \u2192 A],[ancilla_* \u2192 B],[ancilla_* \u2192 C]]  \n in_nodes: []  \n out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector C]  \n anc_detectors: [ancilla_AB det, ancilla_BC det, ancilla_CA det, BSM dets]  \n target_quantum: ['00','11']   (the two-photon Bell outcomes on A,C)  \n amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  (encode the three non-unitary maps)  \n loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 30, ftol: 1e-6, optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving: True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel network primitive: a genuine *percolation* or *multi-site exceptional-point* transition in entanglement distribution across a minimal non-Hermitian graph.  \n\u2013 Tunable & scalable: map out the 3D EP manifold in (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA); Network Description\n\u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n\u2022 On each link ij (i,j\u2208{A,B,C}) the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). A click on that ancilla\u2019s detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 A successful experiment run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. To be novel, present a network effect that cannot be decomposed into individual PT/anti-PT filter+swap blocks\u2014e.g. multi-photon exceptional-point dynamics, topology-protected non-Hermitian percolation with unique bulk/edge behavior, or a distinct non-unitary measurement supermap beyond simple filter concatenation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cTeleportation-Based Anti-PT Quantum Router\u201d for Pytheus to design.  \n\n1. Network overview  \n  \u2022 SPDC produces a Bell pair between modes S (sender) and R1 (receiver 1).  \n  \u2022 A second SPDC pair establishes entanglement between modes R2 (receiver 2) and an auxiliary mode B.  \n  \u2022 The unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 in mode S is to be teleported and then routed to either R1 or R2 by embedding a heralded anti-PT coupler into the Bell\u2010measurement stage.  \n\n2. Router mechanism  \n  a) Bell\u2010measurement node: modes S and B pass through a non-unitary \u201canti-PT coupler\u201d implemented as follows:  \n     \u2013 Each of S and B mixes with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r_S, r_B).  \n     \u2013 A specific click pattern on the two ancilla detectors post-selects the conditional map diag(1,\u03b3) on the joint S\u2013B subspace (\u03b3=r/\u221a(1\u2013r\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n  b) Following heralding, the filtered modes undergo the standard linear-optical Bell\u2010state measurement (BSM).  \n  c) The BSM outcome and the anti-PT herald determine which receiver\u2014R1 or R2\u2014holds the teleported qubit. The effective channel is:  \n     |\u03c8\u27e9_S \u2192 |\u03c8\u27e9_R1 + \u03b3\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_R2  (normalized and conditioned on herald clicks).  \n\n3. Tunable routing  \n  By varying the beam-splitter ratios (i.e. \u03b3), one tunes the router\u2019s bias: below a critical \u03b3_c teleportation flows almost exclusively to R1, above \u03b3_c it flips to R2. At \u03b3_c one observes an exceptional-point in the routing fidelity.  \n\n4. Pytheus configuration (sketch)  \n  description: \u201cTeleportation-based quantum router via a heralded anti-PT coupler.\u201d  \n  foldername: \u201cantiPT_router\u201d  \n  num_anc: 2  \n  single_emitters: [anc_S, anc_B]  \n  removed_connections: [[anc_*\u2192S],[anc_*\u2192B],[anc_*\u2192R1],[anc_*\u2192R2]]  \n  in_nodes: [S]  \n  out_nodes: [R1, R2, BSM_dets]  \n  anc_detectors: [Det_anc_S, Det_anc_B]  \n  target_quantum: design the conditional channel \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_S\u2192\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R1+\u03b3\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R2 (ask Pytheus to realize the isometry on basis states \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9).  \n  amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (non-unitary routing ratio)  \n  loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\n5. Rationale  \n  \u2022 A novel network primitive: teleportation plus non-Hermitian routing\u2014a \u201cquantum switch\u201d controlled by an anti-PT exceptional-point.  \n  \u2022 Tunable threshold phenomenon: scan \u03b3 to observe a phase-transition in routing fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical + heralding toolkit\u2014no forbidden cavities or feedback.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to multi-port routers, higher dimensions, or concatenated routing networks.  \n  \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded beam splitter + ancilla maps to a gain-loss coupler in circuit QED for on-chip non-Hermitian quantum routing.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed \u201cTeleportation-Based Anti-PT Quantum Router\u201d simply embeds the same heralded non-unitary (anti-PT) filter into a Bell-measurement stage to bias teleportation between two receivers. This is essentially the same PT/anti-PT filter + teleportation primitive already covered in previous PT-symmetric filter experiments, and it closely parallels the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip.\u201d No genuinely new network supermap or multi-photon non-Hermitian effect is introduced.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This router reduces to a single anti-PT filter + Bell swap, so it fails to present a novel quantum-network primitive. To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a qualitatively new effect\u2014for example a multi-port non-Hermitian router with true multi-photon exceptional-point dynamics, a topology-protected non-Hermitian routing network, or a non-unitary measurement supermap that cannot be decomposed into existing PT-filter+teleport modules."
