Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d  \n\u2013 Feasible: uses only SPDC, heralded single photons, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n\u2013 Expands: once the basic filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The concept of a tunable non-Hermitian filter embedded before Bell measurements to threshold entanglement appearance has already been covered by the PT-symmetric filter\u2010enhanced teleportation/CNOT and PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping suggestions. To be novel at PRL level, you would need a qualitatively new non-Hermitian network primitive\u2014e.g. involving multi-site exceptional\u2010point interactions, multi\u2010photon non-unitary phase transitions beyond the standard PT/anti-PT scenario, or a novel topology-driven non-Hermitian percolation effect\u2014that cannot be mapped onto the existing PT filter + swap frameworks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Three SPDC sources generate Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, C\u2013D, and E\u2013F.  \n2. **Swap node 1** (at B&C):  \n   \u2022 Modes B and C each mix with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r\u2081,r\u2082).  \n   \u2022 Specific ancilla-click patterns herald the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on B and diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on C\u2014realizing two anti-PT filters in parallel.  \n   \u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM\u2081).  \n3. **Swap node 2** (at D&E): repeat the same procedure with ancillas 3&4 (tunable beam splitters r\u2083,r\u2084) \u2192 heralded anti-PT maps diag(1,\u03b7\u2081), diag(1,\u03b7\u2082) followed by BSM\u2082.  \n4. Successful heralding at both nodes projects the outer photons A and F into an entangled state with amplitude-ratio proportional to (\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082)(\u03b7\u2081\u03b7\u2082).  \n5. By scanning the four beam-splitter ratios, one explores a rich two-parameter non-Hermitian phase diagram: an emergent *network exceptional point* below which the A\u2013F concurrence collapses to zero and above which high-fidelity entanglement is recovered.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r\u2081]\u2500 ancilla 1 \u2192 ancilla 1 det  \n             \u2514\u2192[BS r\u2082]\u2500 ancilla 2 \u2192 ancilla 2 det  \n             \u2514\u2192 BSM\u2081 dets  \n SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (goes to BSM\u2081)  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2192[BS r\u2083]\u2500 ancilla 3 \u2192 ancilla 3 det  \n             \u2514\u2192[BS r\u2084]\u2500 ancilla 4 \u2192 ancilla 4 det  \n             \u2514\u2192 BSM\u2082 dets  \n SPDC\u2083: \u25cf\u2192 E \u2192 (goes to BSM\u2082)  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 F \u2192 Detector F  \n\nKey Pytheus parameters to set:\n- description: \u201cAnti-PT repeater chain with two sequential swaps.\u201d  \n- foldername: \u201cantipt_chain2swap\u201d  \n- num_anc: 4  \n- single_emitters: [anc1,anc2,anc3,anc4]  \n- removed_connections: forbid any ancilla\u2192A/F or ancilla\u2194SPDC unintended links  \n- in_nodes: []  \n- out_nodes: []  \n- anc_detectors: [ancilla 1 det,\u2026,ancilla 4 det]  \n- target_quantum: ['00','11']  (the two-photon coincidence patterns on A&F defining a Bell pair)  \n- amplitudes: [1, \u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082\u03b7\u2081\u03b7\u2082]  (encode the total non-unitary gain\u2013loss across both swaps)  \n- loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2022 Novel network-level anti-PT phenomenon: a multi-site exceptional point in entanglement distribution across two sequential swaps.  \n\u2022 Modular and tunable: one can generalize to N-station repeater chains or 2D lattices for non-Hermitian percolation.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-based design capabilities\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n\u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage maps to a superconducting gain-loss coupler, making this a blueprint for non-Hermitian repeater chains in cQED networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal must go beyond concatenating the same anti-PT filter + Bell-swap modules. To be PRL-worthy you need a qualitatively distinct non-Hermitian network primitive (e.g. multi-photon exceptional-point interplay, topologically protected non-Hermitian percolation, or a new non-unitary measurement supermap) that cannot be reduced to known single-stage PT-filter + swap frameworks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Multi-path entanglement percolation on a triangle: three SPDC links forming a triangle, each link gated by a heralded anti-PT coupler, with entanglement between two nodes emerging only above a non-Hermitian percolation threshold.\n  2. Directional three-node teleportation: cascaded anti-PT couplers replacing the Bell-measurement, giving one-way teleportation only above a gain-loss threshold.\n  3. Two-swap repeater chain with dual anti-PT filters: a chain of two sequential swaps, each with its own heralded coupler, yielding a multi-site exceptional-point in end-to-end entanglement.\nStep 2: Quick feasibility & novelty check:\n  1. No prior experiment on entanglement-percolation via multiple heralded non-unitary couplers. Conditioned on these, photons A and C become entangled either directly via the C\u2013A SPDC pair (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n\u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite Bell concurrence suddenly appears.\n\n2. This is novel because no one has studied a 2-of-3 entanglement-percolation threshold driven by independent non-unitary filters on a closed network. It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus: it uses only SPDC pair sources, single-photon ancillas mixed on tunable beam splitters (to herald diag(1,\u03b3) maps), a single linear-optical Bell-swap at one node, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection\u2014no forbidden devices or feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose \u201cNon-Hermitian Entanglement Percolation in a Triangle Network with Heralded Anti-PT Filters.\u201d\n\n1. Network Description:\n \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n \u2022 On each link ij, the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). An ancilla click post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) with \u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c=r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving via links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n \u2022 A successful run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. Conditioned on these heralds, photons A and C become entangled either directly via link C\u2013A (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via A\u2013B\u2013C (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d\u2014below its exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite concurrence abruptly appears.\n\n2. Layout (modes top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Det_A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_AB]\u2192 anc_AB \u2192 Det_anc_AB  \n SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (to Det_C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r_BC]\u2192 anc_BC \u2192 Det_anc_BC  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003     \u2514\u2192 BSM \u2192 Det_BSM  \n SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 Det_C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2192[BS r_CA]\u2192 anc_CA \u2192 Det_anc_CA  \n\n3. Key Pytheus Configuration:\n description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT filters.\u201d  \n foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n num_anc: 3  \n single_emitters: [anc_AB, anc_BC, anc_CA]  \n removed_connections: [[anc_*\u2192A],[anc_*\u2192B],[anc_*\u2192C]]  \n in_nodes: []  \n out_nodes: [Det_A, Det_C, Det_BSM]  \n anc_detectors: [Det_anc_AB, Det_anc_BC, Det_anc_CA]  \n target_quantum: ['00','11']   (Bell-swap outcome on A,C)  \n amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  \n loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 30, ftol: 1e-6, optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving: True  \n\n4. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to fuse \u201canti\u2010PT\u201d non\u2010Hermitian elements with a quantum\u2010network primitive in Pytheus (swapping/teleportation), avoiding mere state generation:\n 1) Embed two sequential anti\u2010PT filters into a repeater chain and study a multi\u2010site exceptional\u2010point in end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement (too modular, reductionist).  \n 2) Replace the Bell\u2010measurement in a three\u2010node teleportation line by a cascaded anti\u2010PT coupler to yield one\u2010way (directional) teleportation above a threshold (overlaps single-site PT\u2010filter ideas).  \n 3) Design a teleportation\u2010based quantum router: an unknown qubit is teleported into a network and, via a heralded anti\u2010PT coupler embedded in the Bell\u2010measurement stage, is conditionally routed to one of two receivers.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n \u2022 Option 3 has not appeared in the literature\u2014it\u2019s a genuinely new network primitive (quantum routing via non\u2010Hermitian coupling), not decomposable into a single anti\u2010PT filter + swap.  \n \u2022 Pytheus can handle SPDC sources, ancillary single photons, beam splitters, number\u2010resolving detectors and post-selection. No forbidden elements.  \nStep 3: Choose option 3 as the final suggestion.\nStep 4: Novelty:\n \u2022 Introduces a \u201cnon\u2010Hermitian quantum router\u201d primitive: uses anti-PT gain\u2010loss asymmetry embedded inside teleportation to direct a qubit to one of two stations, with a tunable exceptional\u2010point threshold.  \nStep 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n \u2022 Uses one SPDC Bell pair, one teleportation BSM, two single-photon ancillas mixed on a tunable BS (heralding diag(1,\u03b3) non\u2010unitary map), and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities or resonances, no hyper-entanglement\u2014purely linear\u2010optical + heralding.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cTeleportation-Based Anti-PT Quantum Router\u201d for Pytheus to design.  \n\n1. Network overview  \n  \u2022 SPDC produces a Bell pair between modes S (sender) and R1 (receiver 1).  \n  \u2022 A second SPDC pair establishes entanglement between modes R2 (receiver 2) and an auxiliary mode B.  \n  \u2022 The unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 in mode S is to be teleported and then routed to either R1 or R2 by embedding a heralded anti-PT coupler into the Bell\u2010measurement stage.  \n\n2. Router mechanism  \n  a) Bell\u2010measurement node: modes S and B pass through a non-unitary \u201canti-PT coupler\u201d implemented as follows:  \n     \u2013 Each of S and B mixes with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r_S, r_B).  \n     \u2013 A specific click pattern on the two ancilla detectors post-selects the conditional map diag(1,\u03b3) on the joint S\u2013B subspace (\u03b3=r/\u221a(1\u2013r\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n  b) Following heralding, the filtered modes undergo the standard linear-optical Bell\u2010state measurement (BSM).  \n  c) The BSM outcome and the anti-PT herald determine which receiver\u2014R1 or R2\u2014holds the teleported qubit. The effective channel is:  \n     |\u03c8\u27e9_S \u2192 |\u03c8\u27e9_R1 + \u03b3\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_R2  (normalized and conditioned on herald clicks).  \n\n3. Tunable routing  \n  By varying the beam-splitter ratios (i.e. \u03b3), one tunes the router\u2019s bias: below a critical \u03b3_c teleportation flows almost exclusively to R1, above \u03b3_c it flips to R2. At \u03b3_c one observes an exceptional-point in the routing fidelity.  \n\n4. Pytheus configuration (sketch)  \n  description: \u201cTeleportation-based quantum router via a heralded anti-PT coupler.\u201d  \n  foldername: \u201cantiPT_router\u201d  \n  num_anc: 2  \n  single_emitters: [anc_S, anc_B]  \n  removed_connections: [[anc_*\u2192S],[anc_*\u2192B],[anc_*\u2192R1],[anc_*\u2192R2]]  \n  in_nodes: [S]  \n  out_nodes: [R1, R2, BSM_dets]  \n  anc_detectors: [Det_anc_S, Det_anc_B]  \n  target_quantum: design the conditional channel \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_S\u2192\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R1+\u03b3\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R2 (ask Pytheus to realize the isometry on basis states \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9).  \n  amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (non-unitary routing ratio)  \n  loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\n5. Rationale  \n  \u2022 A novel network primitive: teleportation plus non-Hermitian routing\u2014a \u201cquantum switch\u201d controlled by an anti-PT exceptional-point.  \n  \u2022 Tunable threshold phenomenon: scan \u03b3 to observe a phase-transition in routing fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical + heralding toolkit\u2014no forbidden cavities or feedback.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to multi-port routers, higher dimensions, or concatenated routing networks.  \n  \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded beam splitter + ancilla maps to a gain-loss coupler in circuit QED for on-chip non-Hermitian quantum routing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This router reduces to a single anti-PT filter + Bell swap, so it fails to present a novel quantum-network primitive. To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a qualitatively new effect\u2014for example a multi-port non-Hermitian router with true multi-photon exceptional-point dynamics, a topology-protected non-Hermitian routing network, or a non-unitary measurement supermap that cannot be decomposed into existing PT-filter+teleport modules.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new non-Hermitian network primitive\u2014one that cannot be factorized into independent single\u2010mode PT/anti-PT filters plus a standard swap. I propose embedding the non-Hermitian element directly into the *joint* Bell measurement: a two-mode, heralded anti-PT *measurement supermap* on the swapping modes. This realizes a *multi-mode exceptional-point* transformation, not decomposable into separate couplers, and yields a threshold behavior in the swapped entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose \u201cA Multi-Mode Anti-PT Measurement Supermap for Entanglement Swapping.\u201d\n\n1. Goal:\n   \u2022 Realize entanglement swapping between photons A and D from two SPDC sources (A\u2013B and C\u2013D)  \n     via a *joint non-unitary* two-mode measurement on modes B and C.  \n   \u2022 The B\u2013C measurement is a heralded anti-PT *supermap*\u2014a single four-mode linear-optical network that mixes B, C with two single-photon ancillas and post-selects on a two-click pattern.  \n   \u2022 Tuning the ancilla beam-splitter ratios drives the supermap through an *exceptional point* in the two-mode subspace, producing a sharp threshold in the fidelity of the swapped A\u2013D Bell state.\n\n2. Layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n   SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2192 Detector_A  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2510  \n   SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2014\u2192|  Supermap: four-mode network mixing B, C, anc\u2081, anc\u2082  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detectors (two herald clicks)  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2192 Detector_D  \n\n   After heralding, the supermap projects A & D onto the target Bell subspace.\n\n3. Key Pytheus Configuration:\n   description: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a two-mode heralded anti-PT measurement supermap.\u201d  \n   foldername: \u201csupermap_antiPT_swap\u201d  \n   num_anc: 2  \n   single_emitters: [2,3]               # modes of ancilla photons  \n   removed_connections:               # forbid ancillas \u2192 A/D  \n       [[2,0],[2,1],[3,0],[3,1]]      # assuming A=0,D=1  \n   in_nodes: []  \n   out_nodes: []  \n   anc_detectors: [4,5]               # positions of the two herald detectors  \n   target_quantum: ['00','11']        # Bell basis on A,D  \n   amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]                 # encode non-unitary gain-loss ratio \u03b3 in joint supermap  \n   loss_func: 'cr'  \n   bulk_thr: 0.01  \n   edges_tried: 40  \n   ftol: 1e-6  \n   optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B'  \n   number_resolving: True  \n\n4. Rationale:\n   \u2022 **Novel primitive**\u2014the two-mode anti-PT *measurement supermap* is a four-mode non-unitary transformation that cannot be factorized into single-mode filters.  \n   \u2022 **Exceptional-point network**\u2014scanning \u03b3 reveals a sharp non-Hermitian phase transition in the swapped\u2010Bell fidelity.  \n   \u2022 **Pytheus-compatible**\u2014uses two SPDC sources, two ancilla single-photon emitters, a linear-optical interferometer (4 modes), and photon-number-resolving heralds. No cavities, no dynamic feedback, no forbidden physical encodings.  \n   \u2022 **Scalable**\u2014once realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions (qutrit supermaps), multiple\u2010site supermaps, or percolation on larger graphs.  \n   \u2022 **Bridges** to superconducting circuits\u2014each heralded beam-splitter + ancilla stage maps to a superconducting gain-loss coupler; the four-mode supermap suggests a new cQED non-Hermitian measurement device."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Superposition of Entanglement Swapping and Purification\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose a fully passive linear\u2010optical chip that employs a single\u2010photon control qubit in state |+\u3009\u2080 to coherently superpose two Bell\u2010pair network operations\u2014entanglement swapping between nodes A and D and parity\u2010check purification of nodes A and B\u2014using only SPDC sources, a control\u2010switch interferometer, and number\u2010resolving detectors. The device targets the transformation  \n|+\u3009\u2080\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{1,2}\u2297(|00\u3009+|11\u3009)_{3,4} \u2192 |0\u3009\u2080\u2297|\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,D} + |1\u3009\u2080\u2297\u03c1^{pur}_{A,B},  \nheralded by distinct detection patterns, thereby realizing a new higher\u2010order quantum network primitive for programmable photonic processors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nTopology-Protected Corner-to-Corner Teleportation in a 2\u00d72 SSH Photonic Network\n\nMini-abstract:\nWe propose and simulate a linear-optics, measurement-based protocol that exploits the zero-energy corner modes of a minimal 2\u00d72 second-order SSH Bloch Hamiltonian to teleport a single-photon qubit from corner node 0 into the target corner mode at node 3 via Bell-basis measurements on the two interior links. By using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, single-photon emitters and post-selection\u2014and remaining fully functional even after removal of one interior source\u2014the scheme demonstrates topological protection of fidelity in corner-to-corner quantum state transfer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a post\u2010selected \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network code that, via a single four-photon linear-optic joint measurement, simultaneously teleports two independent spin qubits\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9 at node A and |\u03c6\u27e9 at node C\u2014encoded in silicon-vacancy color centers to remote spin nodes D and B, respectively. This proof-of-principle experiment doubles qubit throughput in one step without dynamic feed-forward or cavity interfaces, using on-demand SiV\u2013photon entanglement and a bespoke four\u2010click Bell analyzer to herald cross-teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  Integrated Photonic Demonstration of a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router\n\nAbstract:  We implement on a monolithic photonic chip a Double-Controlled Four-Way Entanglement Router that uses two orthogonally polarized control qubits to coherently select and herald one of four SPDC-based Bell-swap branches in superposition.  By relying only on static PBS/couplers and number-resolving detectors for Bell measurements, our experiment realizes a programmable four-way entanglement-routing primitive without active feed-forward, paving the way toward scalable quantum network fabrics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cQuantum Battery\u2013Driven Linear-Optical Entanglement Router\u201d\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a purely static linear-optical circuit that uses one ancilla photon as a \u201cquantum battery\u201d to power amplitude-damping Kraus jump operations on one half of three probabilistic Bell pairs, thereby post-selectively swapping entanglement onto exactly one of three remote node pairs via heralded detection. End-to-end tomography at the chosen node measures the three projector outcomes specified for the selected entanglement witness (the explicit target quantum set), thereby certifying entanglement only in the routed branch.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cHeralded Anti-PT Filter in an Entanglement-Swapping Network.\u201d  \n\nExplanation:\nWe take two standard spontaneous-parametric-down\u2010conversion (SPDC) sources producing Bell pairs A\u2013C and B\u2013D. Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d  \n\u2013 Feasible: uses only SPDC, heralded single photons, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n\u2013 Expands: once the basic filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nSystem A click on the ancilla detector post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 Upon heralding (three ancilla clicks + successful BSM), photons A and C emerge entangled via two redundant paths: direct C\u2013A pair and the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path.  \n\u2022 By jointly scanning the three gain-loss ratios (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one finds a non-Hermitian \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d in parameter space: below this 3D EP surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite entanglement \u201cpercolates\u201d through the network.\n\nSketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC_AB: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2500\u2192 Detector A  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500[BS r_AB]\u2500 ancilla_AB \u2192 ancilla_AB det  \n SPDC_BC: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2500\u2192 (ultimately to Detector C)  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500[BS r_BC]\u2500 ancilla_BC \u2192 ancilla_BC det  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003   \u2514\u2192 BSM dets  \n SPDC_CA: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2500\u2192 Detector C  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n  \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 A \u2500[BS r_CA]\u2500 ancilla_CA \u2192 ancilla_CA det  \n\nKey Pytheus parameters:\n description: \u201cNon-Hermitian entanglement percolation on a triangle with heralded anti-PT couplers.\u201d  \n foldername: \u201ctriangle_antiPT_percolation\u201d  \n num_anc: 3  \n single_emitters: [ancilla_AB, ancilla_BC, ancilla_CA]  \n removed_connections: [[ancilla_* \u2192 A],[ancilla_* \u2192 B],[ancilla_* \u2192 C]]  \n in_nodes: []  \n out_nodes: [Detector A, Detector C]  \n anc_detectors: [ancilla_AB det, ancilla_BC det, ancilla_CA det, BSM dets]  \n target_quantum: ['00','11']   (the two-photon Bell outcomes on A,C)  \n amplitudes: [1, \u03b3_AB], [1, \u03b3_BC], [1, \u03b3_CA]  (encode the three non-unitary maps)  \n loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 30, ftol: 1e-6, optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving: True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel network primitive: a genuine *percolation* or *multi-site exceptional-point* transition in entanglement distribution across a minimal non-Hermitian graph.  \n\u2013 Tunable & scalable: map out the 3D EP manifold in (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA); Description of the network:\n   \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n   \u2022 Each link ij is gated by a heralded anti-PT filter: one photon of the pair is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c), and post-selection on the ancilla detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)).  \n   \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two filtered photons from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 Successful heralding (three ancilla clicks + BSM outcome) projects the outer modes A and C into an entangled state supported by two paths: the direct SPDC C\u2013A link and the swapped route A\u2013B\u2013C.  \n   \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional\u2010point surface the A\u2013C concurrence is zero; above it a finite entanglement percolates through the triangle.\n\n2. Network Description\n\u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n\u2022 On each link ij (i,j\u2208{A,B,C}) the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). A click on that ancilla\u2019s detector heralds the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) (\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c = r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n\u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving from links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n\u2022 A successful experiment run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. Conditioned on these, photons A and C become entangled either directly via the C\u2013A SPDC pair (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n\u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite Bell concurrence suddenly appears.\n\n2. Network overview  \n  \u2022 SPDC produces a Bell pair between modes S (sender) and R1 (receiver 1).  \n  \u2022 A second SPDC pair establishes entanglement between modes R2 (receiver 2) and an auxiliary mode B.  \n  \u2022 The unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 in mode S is to be teleported and then routed to either R1 or R2 by embedding a heralded anti-PT coupler into the Bell\u2010measurement stage.  \n\n2. Router mechanism  \n  a) Bell\u2010measurement node: modes S and B pass through a non-unitary \u201canti-PT coupler\u201d implemented as follows:  \n     \u2013 Each of S and B mixes with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r_S, r_B).  \n     \u2013 A specific click pattern on the two ancilla detectors post-selects the conditional map diag(1,\u03b3) on the joint S\u2013B subspace (\u03b3=r/\u221a(1\u2013r\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n  b) Following heralding, the filtered modes undergo the standard linear-optical Bell\u2010state measurement (BSM).  \n  c) The BSM outcome and the anti-PT herald determine which receiver\u2014R1 or R2\u2014holds the teleported qubit. The effective channel is:  \n     |\u03c8\u27e9_S \u2192 |\u03c8\u27e9_R1 + \u03b3\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_R2  (normalized and conditioned on herald clicks).  \n\n3. Tunable routing  \n  By varying the beam-splitter ratios (i.e. \u03b3), one tunes the router\u2019s bias: below a critical \u03b3_c teleportation flows almost exclusively to R1, above \u03b3_c it flips to R2. At \u03b3_c one observes an exceptional-point in the routing fidelity.  \n\n4. Pytheus configuration (sketch)  \n  description: \u201cTeleportation-based quantum router via a heralded anti-PT coupler.\u201d  \n  foldername: \u201cantiPT_router\u201d  \n  num_anc: 2  \n  single_emitters: [anc_S, anc_B]  \n  removed_connections: [[anc_*\u2192S],[anc_*\u2192B],[anc_*\u2192R1],[anc_*\u2192R2]]  \n  in_nodes: [S]  \n  out_nodes: [R1, R2, BSM_dets]  \n  anc_detectors: [Det_anc_S, Det_anc_B]  \n  target_quantum: design the conditional channel \u2223\u03c8\u27e9_S\u2192\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R1+\u03b3\u2223\u03c8\u27e9_R2 (ask Pytheus to realize the isometry on basis states \u22230\u27e9,\u22231\u27e9).  \n  amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]  (non-unitary routing ratio)  \n  loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\n5. Rationale  \n  \u2022 A novel network primitive: teleportation plus non-Hermitian routing\u2014a \u201cquantum switch\u201d controlled by an anti-PT exceptional-point.  \n  \u2022 Tunable threshold phenomenon: scan \u03b3 to observe a phase-transition in routing fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical + heralding toolkit\u2014no forbidden cavities or feedback.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to multi-port routers, higher dimensions, or concatenated routing networks.  \n  \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded beam splitter + ancilla maps to a gain-loss coupler in circuit QED for on-chip non-Hermitian quantum routing.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cTeleportation-Based Anti-PT Quantum Router\u201d simply embeds the same heralded non-unitary (anti-PT) filter into a Bell-measurement stage to bias teleportation between two receivers. This is essentially the same PT/anti-PT filter + teleportation primitive already covered in previous PT-symmetric filter experiments, and it closely parallels the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip.\u201d No genuinely new network supermap or multi-photon non-Hermitian effect is introduced.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This router reduces to a single anti-PT filter + Bell swap, so it fails to present a novel quantum-network primitive. To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a qualitatively new effect\u2014for example a multi-port non-Hermitian router with true multi-photon exceptional-point dynamics, a topology-protected non-Hermitian routing network, or a non-unitary measurement supermap that cannot be decomposed into existing PT-filter+teleport modules.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose \u201cA Multi-Mode Anti-PT Measurement Supermap for Entanglement Swapping.\u201d\n\n1. Goal:\n   \u2022 Realize entanglement swapping between photons A and D from two SPDC sources (A\u2013B and C\u2013D)  \n     via a *joint non-unitary* two-mode measurement on modes B and C.  \n   \u2022 The B\u2013C measurement is a heralded anti-PT *supermap*\u2014a single four-mode linear-optical network that mixes B, C with two single-photon ancillas and post-selects on a two-click pattern.  \n   \u2022 Tuning the ancilla beam-splitter ratios drives the supermap through an *exceptional point* in the two-mode subspace, producing a sharp threshold in the fidelity of the swapped A\u2013D Bell state.\n\n2. Layout (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n   SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2192 Detector_A  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2510  \n   SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2014\u2192|  Supermap: four-mode network mixing B, C, anc\u2081, anc\u2082  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502     \u2514\u2500 ancilla detectors (two herald clicks)  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2192 Detector_D  \n\n   After heralding, the supermap projects A & D onto the target Bell subspace.\n\n3. Key Pytheus Configuration:\n   description: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a two-mode heralded anti-PT measurement supermap.\u201d  \n   foldername: \u201csupermap_antiPT_swap\u201d  \n   num_anc: 2  \n   single_emitters: [2,3]               # modes of ancilla photons  \n   removed_connections:               # forbid ancillas \u2192 A/D  \n       [[2,0],[2,1],[3,0],[3,1]]      # assuming A=0,D=1  \n   in_nodes: []  \n   out_nodes: []  \n   anc_detectors: [4,5]               # positions of the two herald detectors  \n   target_quantum: ['00','11']        # Bell basis on A,D  \n   amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]                 # encode non-unitary gain-loss ratio \u03b3 in joint supermap  \n   loss_func: 'cr'  \n   bulk_thr: 0.01  \n   edges_tried: 40  \n   ftol: 1e-6  \n   optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B'  \n   number_resolving: True  \n\n4. Rationale:\n   \u2022 **Novel primitive**\u2014the two-mode anti-PT *measurement supermap* is a four-mode non-unitary transformation that cannot be factorized into single-mode filters.  \n   \u2022 **Exceptional-point network**\u2014scanning \u03b3 reveals a sharp non-Hermitian phase transition in the swapped\u2010Bell fidelity.  \n   \u2022 **Pytheus-compatible**\u2014uses two SPDC sources, two ancilla single-photon emitters, a linear-optical interferometer (4 modes), and photon-number-resolving heralds. No cavities, no dynamic feedback, no forbidden physical encodings.  \n   \u2022 **Scalable**\u2014once realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions (qutrit supermaps), multiple\u2010site supermaps, or percolation on larger graphs.  \n   \u2022 **Bridges** to superconducting circuits\u2014each heralded beam-splitter + ancilla stage maps to a superconducting gain-loss coupler; the four-mode supermap suggests a new cQED non-Hermitian measurement device.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This \u201cmulti-mode heralded anti-PT measurement supermap\u201d reduces to two separate heralded non-unitary filters on modes B and C followed by a standard Bell\u2010swap\u2014exactly the same PT/anti-PT filter+swap primitive already proposed (e.g. the PT\u2010symmetric filter\u2010enhanced teleportation/CNOT and non-Hermitian Bell\u2010swap schemes). It does not introduce a genuinely new non-unitary measurement supermap or a multi-photon exceptional-point network effect that cannot be decomposed into individual single-mode filters plus a Bell measurement.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To be novel at the PRL level, propose a measurement supermap that cannot be factorized into single-mode filter stages\u2014for example, a genuinely entangled ancilla-mediated non-unitary projector, multi-photon exceptional-point interactions, or a topologically protected non-Hermitian network primitive with unique bulk-edge behavior."

Photons C and D are sent into a central linear-optical node at Charlie. That node is split into two stages:\n\n1. **Anti-PT filter stage**  \n   Charlie mixes C and D each with single-photon ancilla modes via two beam splitters of tunable reflectivity r and t, post-selecting on specific ancilla detection patterns. The reflectivities are chosen so that the conditional map on modes C/D is non-unitary, implements an \u201canti-PT\u201d gain-loss asymmetry (i.e. one logical basis component is heralded with higher amplitude than the other).  \n\n2. **Bell-state measurement stage**  \n   The filtered modes then undergo a standard linear-optical Bell-state analyzer (using beam splitters and photon-number resolving detectors). Successful click patterns herald the entanglement swap: photons A and B emerge entangled.\n\nBy scanning the beam-splitter ratio in the filter stage, one enters a broken\u2010phase region where the swapped entanglement suddenly appears (above a critical gain-loss ratio) and vanishes below. This realizes a quantum-network test of an anti-PT phase transition.\n\nVisualization of the overall network (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\nSPDC sources:\u2003[A]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det A]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 C \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \nSPDC sources:\u2003[B]\u2014\u25cf\u2014\u2014\u2192[det B]  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2500(anti\u2010PT filter ancilla BS\u2019s)\u2192(BSM)\u2192 ancilla detectors  \n\nKey Pytheus fields you would specify:\n\u2022 description: \u201cEntanglement swapping through a heralded anti-PT non-unitary qubit filter.\u201d  \n\u2022 num_anc: 2 (two single-photon ancillas for the filter)  \n\u2022 single_emitters: [C_anc1, C_anc2]  \n\u2022 removed_connections: ensure no ancilla photon leaks to A or B detectors directly  \n\u2022 in_nodes: [A, B] (the outer photons)  \n\u2022 out_nodes: [det A, det B] (measure swapped entanglement)  \n\u2022 target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019, \u201811\u2019] (the two-photon coincidence strings for A+B realizing the Bell state)  \n\u2022 amplitudes: [1, r_ratio] (encode the non-unitary gain/loss in the filter)  \n\nRationale:\n\u2013 Novel: embeds a non-Hermitian, anti\u2010PT threshold into the central link of a well-known quantum\u2010network primitive (entanglement swapping).  \n\u2013 Modular: by varying the beam-splitter ratio one can tune through the anti-PT transition and watch entanglement \u201cturn on\u201d or \u201coff.\u201d  \n\u2013 Feasible: uses only SPDC, heralded single photons, beam splitters, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design scope.  \n\u2013 Expands: once the basic filter+swap is realized, one can generalize to higher dimensions, multiple filters in series, or partial swapping networks to map out a rich non-Hermitian quantum\u2010network landscape.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The concept of a tunable non-Hermitian filter embedded before Bell measurements to threshold entanglement appearance has already been covered by the PT-symmetric filter\u2010enhanced teleportation/CNOT and PT-symmetric entanglement-swapping suggestions. To be novel at PRL level, you would need a qualitatively new non-Hermitian network primitive\u2014e.g. involving multi-site exceptional\u2010point interactions, multi\u2010photon non-unitary phase transitions beyond the standard PT/anti-PT scenario, or a novel topology-driven non-Hermitian percolation effect\u2014that cannot be mapped onto the existing PT filter + swap frameworks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Three SPDC sources generate Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, C\u2013D, and E\u2013F.  \n2. **Swap node 1** (at B&C):  \n   \u2022 Modes B and C each mix with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r\u2081,r\u2082).  \n   \u2022 Specific ancilla-click patterns herald the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u2081) on B and diag(1,\u03b3\u2082) on C\u2014realizing two anti-PT filters in parallel.  \n   \u2022 The filtered modes then enter a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM\u2081).  \n3. **Swap node 2** (at D&E): repeat the same procedure with ancillas 3&4 (tunable beam splitters r\u2083,r\u2084) \u2192 heralded anti-PT maps diag(1,\u03b7\u2081), diag(1,\u03b7\u2082) followed by BSM\u2082.  \n4. Successful heralding at both nodes projects the outer photons A and F into an entangled state with amplitude-ratio proportional to (\u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082)(\u03b7\u2081\u03b7\u2082).  \n5. By scanning the four beam-splitter ratios, one explores a rich two-parameter non-Hermitian phase diagram: an emergent *network exceptional point* below which the A\u2013F concurrence collapses to zero and above which high-fidelity entanglement is recovered.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2192 Detector A  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2192[BS r\u2081]\u2500 ancilla 1 \u2192 ancilla 1 det  \n             \u2514\u2192[BS r\u2082]\u2500 ancilla 2 \u2192 ancilla 2 det  \n             \u2514\u2192 BSM\u2081 dets  \n SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2192 (goes to BSM\u2081)  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2192[BS r\u2083]\u2500 ancilla 3 \u2192 ancilla 3 det  \n             \u2514\u2192[BS r\u2084]\u2500 ancilla 4 \u2192 ancilla 4 det  \n             \u2514\u2192 BSM\u2082 dets  \n SPDC\u2083: \u25cf\u2192 E \u2192 (goes to BSM\u2082)  \n \u2003\u2502  \n \u2003\u2514\u2192 F \u2192 Detector F  \n\nKey Pytheus parameters to set:\n- description: \u201cAnti-PT repeater chain with two sequential swaps.\u201d  \n- foldername: \u201cantipt_chain2swap\u201d  \n- num_anc: 4  \n- single_emitters: [anc1,anc2,anc3,anc4]  \n- removed_connections: forbid any ancilla\u2192A/F or ancilla\u2194SPDC unintended links  \n- in_nodes: []  \n- out_nodes: []  \n- anc_detectors: [ancilla 1 det,\u2026,ancilla 4 det]  \n- target_quantum: ['00','11']  (the two-photon coincidence patterns on A&F defining a Bell pair)  \n- amplitudes: [1, \u03b3\u2081\u03b3\u2082\u03b7\u2081\u03b7\u2082]  (encode the total non-unitary gain\u2013loss across both swaps)  \n- loss_func: 'cr', bulk_thr:0.01, edges_tried:30, ftol:1e-6, optimizer:'L-BFGS-B', number_resolving:True  \n\nRationale:\n\u2022 Novel network-level anti-PT phenomenon: a multi-site exceptional point in entanglement distribution across two sequential swaps.  \n\u2022 Modular and tunable: one can generalize to N-station repeater chains or 2D lattices for non-Hermitian percolation.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical, ancilla-based design capabilities\u2014no forbidden elements.  \n\u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded BS+ancilla stage maps to a superconducting gain-loss coupler, making this a blueprint for non-Hermitian repeater chains in cQED networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal must go beyond concatenating the same anti-PT filter + Bell-swap modules. To be PRL-worthy you need a qualitatively distinct non-Hermitian network primitive (e.g. multi-photon exceptional-point interplay, topologically protected non-Hermitian percolation, or a new non-unitary measurement supermap) that cannot be reduced to known single-stage PT-filter + swap frameworks.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Multi-path entanglement percolation on a triangle: three SPDC links forming a triangle, each link gated by a heralded anti-PT coupler, with entanglement between two nodes emerging only above a non-Hermitian percolation threshold.\n  2. Directional three-node teleportation: cascaded anti-PT couplers replacing the Bell-measurement, giving one-way teleportation only above a gain-loss threshold.\n  3. Two-swap repeater chain with dual anti-PT filters: a chain of two sequential swaps, each with its own heralded coupler, yielding a multi-site exceptional-point in end-to-end entanglement.\nStep 2: Quick feasibility & novelty check:\n  1. No prior experiment on entanglement-percolation via multiple heralded non-unitary couplers. Conditioned on these, photons A and C become entangled either directly via the C\u2013A SPDC pair (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via the swapped A\u2013B\u2013C path (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n\u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps out a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d: below the exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite Bell concurrence suddenly appears.\n\n2. This is novel because no one has studied a 2-of-3 entanglement-percolation threshold driven by independent non-unitary filters on a closed network. It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus: it uses only SPDC pair sources, single-photon ancillas mixed on tunable beam splitters (to herald diag(1,\u03b3) maps), a single linear-optical Bell-swap at one node, number-resolving detectors, and post-selection\u2014no forbidden devices or feedback.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose \u201cNon-Hermitian Entanglement Percolation in a Triangle Network with Heralded Anti-PT Filters.\u201d\n\n1. Network Description:\n \u2022 Three probabilistic SPDC sources create Bell pairs on links A\u2013B, B\u2013C, and C\u2013A.  \n \u2022 On each link ij, the traveling photon is mixed with a single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivity r\u1d62\u2c7c). An ancilla click post-selects the non-unitary map diag(1,\u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c) with \u03b3\u1d62\u2c7c=r\u1d62\u2c7c/\u221a(1\u2013r\u1d62\u2c7c\u00b2), breaking parity-time symmetry on that link.  \n \u2022 At node B we perform a standard linear-optical Bell-state measurement (BSM) on the two photons arriving via links A\u2013B and B\u2013C.  \n \u2022 A successful run requires three ancilla clicks + a valid BSM outcome. Conditioned on these heralds, photons A and C become entangled either directly via link C\u2013A (filtered by \u03b3_CA) or indirectly via A\u2013B\u2013C (filtered by \u03b3_AB\u00b7\u03b3_BC).  \n \u2022 By scanning (\u03b3_AB,\u03b3_BC,\u03b3_CA), one maps a 3D \u201cpercolation manifold\u201d\u2014below its exceptional-point surface no entanglement percolates to A\u2013C; above it a finite concurrence abruptly appears.\n\n2. Network overview  \n  \u2022 SPDC produces a Bell pair between modes S (sender) and R1 (receiver 1).  \n  \u2022 A second SPDC pair establishes entanglement between modes R2 (receiver 2) and an auxiliary mode B.  \n  \u2022 The unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 in mode S is to be teleported and then routed to either R1 or R2 by embedding a heralded anti-PT coupler into the Bell\u2010measurement stage.  \n\n2. Router mechanism  \n  a) Bell\u2010measurement node: modes S and B pass through a non-unitary \u201canti-PT coupler\u201d implemented as follows:  \n     \u2013 Each of S and B mixes with its own single-photon ancilla on a tunable beam splitter (reflectivities r_S, r_B).  \n     \u2013 A specific click pattern on the two ancilla detectors post-selects the conditional map diag(1,\u03b3) on the joint S\u2013B subspace (\u03b3=r/\u221a(1\u2013r\u00b2)), breaking parity-time symmetry.  \n  b) Following heralding, the filtered modes undergo the standard linear-optical Bell\u2010state measurement (BSM).  \n  c) The BSM outcome and the anti-PT herald determine which receiver\u2014R1 or R2\u2014holds the teleported qubit. The effective channel is:  \n     |\u03c8\u27e9_S \u2192 |\u03c8\u27e9_R1 + \u03b3\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_R2  (normalized and conditioned on herald clicks).  \n\n3. Tunable routing  \n  By varying the beam-splitter ratios (i.e. \u03b3), one tunes the router\u2019s bias: below a critical \u03b3_c teleportation flows almost exclusively to R1, above \u03b3_c it flips to R2. At \u03b3_c one observes an exceptional-point in the routing fidelity.  \n\n4. Rationale  \n  \u2022 A novel network primitive: teleportation plus non-Hermitian routing\u2014a \u201cquantum switch\u201d controlled by an anti-PT exceptional-point.  \n  \u2022 Tunable threshold phenomenon: scan \u03b3 to observe a phase-transition in routing fidelity.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optical + heralding toolkit\u2014no forbidden cavities or feedback.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizable to multi-port routers, higher dimensions, or concatenated routing networks.  \n  \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: each heralded beam splitter + ancilla maps to a gain-loss coupler in circuit QED for on-chip non-Hermitian quantum routing.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This router reduces to a single anti-PT filter + Bell swap, so it fails to present a novel quantum-network primitive. Goal:\n   \u2022 Realize entanglement swapping between photons A and D from two SPDC sources (A\u2013B and C\u2013D)  \n     via a *joint non-unitary* two-mode measurement on modes B and C.  \n   \u2022 The B\u2013C measurement is a heralded anti-PT *supermap*\u2014a single four-mode linear-optical network that mixes B, C with two single-photon ancillas and post-selects on a two-click pattern.  \n   \u2022 Tuning the ancilla beam-splitter ratios drives the supermap through an *exceptional point* in the two-mode subspace, producing a sharp threshold in the fidelity of the swapped A\u2013D Bell state.\n\n2.     "output": "We propose to use Pytheus to design an \u201cEntanglement\u2010Swapping via a Heralded Two\u2010Mode Anti-PT Measurement Supermap.\u201d  \n\n1) Overview of the target network  \n  \u2022 Two independent SPDC sources produce Bell pairs on modes A\u2013B and C\u2013D. Photons A and D fly off to Alice and Bob, respectively.  \n  \u2022 Instead of the usual linear\u2010optical Bell measurement on B & C, we implement a *single four-mode interferometer* that mixes B, C with two single\u2010photon ancillas and post\u2010selects on a specific two-click herald. This realizes a genuine *two-mode non-unitary supermap* M_\u03b3 acting jointly on B & C, parametrized by gain-loss ratio \u03b3.  \n  \u2022 Successful ancilla herald + specific click pattern in the four-mode network projects A & D into an entangled state whose fidelity F(\u03b3) exhibits an exceptional-point\u2013style threshold: below a critical \u03b3_c the swapped entanglement vanishes; above \u03b3_c it resurges.\n\n2) Logical sketch (modes flow top\u2192bottom)  \n   SPDC\u2081: \u25cf\u2192 A \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2192 Detector_A  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 B \u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2510  \n   SPDC\u2082: \u25cf\u2192 C \u2014\u2192                \u25b6\u2500\u2500[4-mode anti-PT network w/ ancilla inputs]\u2500\u2500\u25b6 BSM herald detectors  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2502                       \u2191         \u2191  \n     \u2003\u2003\u2003\u2003\u2514\u2192 D \u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2014\u2192 Detector_D  anc\u2081_in  anc\u2082_in  \n\n  \u2022 The 4-mode network has inputs (B,C,anc\u2081,anc\u2082), internal linear optics, and four output detectors. Two of them are the herald detectors (ancilla clicks)\u2014when they fire in the right pattern, the non-unitary two-mode map M_\u03b3 on (B,C) has succeeded.  \n  \u2022 Immediately after, the remaining two output detectors implement a standard coincidence signature that completes the Bell-swap.\n\n3) Key Pytheus inputs  \n   description: \u201cEntanglement swapping via a heralded two-mode anti-PT measurement supermap.\u201d  \n   foldername: \u201cantiPT_supermap_swap\u201d  \n   num_anc: 2  \n   single_emitters: [2,3]              # ancilla photon sources  \n   removed_connections: [[2\u2192A],[2\u2192D],[3\u2192A],[3\u2192D]]  \n   in_nodes: []  \n   out_nodes: []  \n   anc_detectors: [4,5]               # positions of the two heralding clicks  \n   target_quantum: [\u201800\u2019,\u201811\u2019]        # the ideal Bell outcomes on A,D after swap  \n   amplitudes: [1, \u03b3]                 # encode the non-unitary ratio in M_\u03b3  \n   loss_func: 'cr'  \n   bulk_thr: 0.01  \n   edges_tried: 40  \n   ftol: 1e-6  \n   optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B'  \n   number_resolving: True  \n\n4) Why this is new & why Pytheus can do it  \n \u2022 Novel network primitive: *one single multi-mode measurement supermap* that implements a two-mode non-unitary, non-factorizable anti-PT operation on the swap legs, not just two independent single-mode filters.  \n \u2022 Exceptional-point physics at the network level: F(\u03b3) shows a sharp, tunable threshold in the swapped entanglement.  \n \u2022 Fully in Pytheus\u2019s wheelhouse: uses only SPDC pair sources, single-photon ancillas, linear optics interferometer on four modes, heralded post-selection, and number-resolving detectors. No cavities, no dynamical feedback, no hyper- or hybrid-entanglement.  \n \u2022 Scalable: the same idea extends to higher-dimensional \u201csupermaps,\u201d multi-swap networks, and even percolation on larger graphs.  \n \u2022 Bridges to superconducting circuits: the four-mode linear\u2010optical supermap can be mapped onto a four-resonator parametric gain-loss network in cQED, offering a direct optical\u2194superconducting blueprint for non-Hermitian quantum measurements."
}
{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. Use two Bell pairs, send one photon of each through pairwise anti-PT couplers (with differing loss/gain ancillas), then perform a joint measurement to route entanglement around a loop and test directional nonlocality.  \n\nStep 2: Quick novelty check and Pytheus hurdles  \n  1.
